title: Towards Energy-Efficient Distributed Agreement
comment: To appear at PODC 2025 as brief announcement
summary:
We study fault-tolerant consensus in a variant of the synchronous message
passing model, where, in each round, every node can choose to be awake or
asleep. This is known as the sleeping model (Chatterjee, Gmyr, Pandurangan PODC
2020) and defines the awake complexity (also called \emph{energy complexity}),
which measures the maximum number of rounds that any node is awake throughout
the execution. Only awake nodes can send and receive messages in a given round
and all messages sent to sleeping nodes are lost. We present new deterministic
consensus algorithms that tolerate up to $f<n$ crash failures, where $n$ is the
number of nodes. Our algorithms match the optimal time complexity lower bound
of $f+1$ rounds. For multi-value consensus, where the input values are chosen
from some possibly large set, we achieve an energy complexity of ${O}(\lceil
f^2 / n \rceil)$ rounds, whereas for binary consensus, we show that ${O}(\lceil
f / \sqrt{n} \rceil)$ rounds are possible.

AI.tldr: The paper presents deterministic consensus algorithms in a synchronous sleeping model, achieving optimal time and efficient energy complexity for crash-tolerant consensus.
AI.motivation: To optimize energy (awake complexity) and time complexity in fault-tolerant consensus within the sleeping synchronous message-passing model.
AI.method: The study proposes deterministic algorithms for consensus, addressing crash-failure tolerance and optimizing energy-aware protocol design.
AI.result: Optimal time of $f+1$ rounds achieved; Multi-value consensus has an energy complexity of $O(\lceil f^2 / n \rceil)$, and binary consensus achieves $O(\lceil f / \sqrt{n} \rceil)$ energy complexity.
AI.conclusion: The algorithms presented provide both time-optimal performance and substantial energy savings in crash-tolerant consensus scenarios within the sleeping model.

title: Efficient Unified Caching for Accelerating Heterogeneous AI Workloads
summary:
Modern AI clusters, which host diverse workloads like data pre-processing,
training and inference, often store the large-volume data in cloud storage and
employ caching frameworks to facilitate remote data access. To avoid
code-intrusion complexity and minimize cache space wastage, it is desirable to
maintain a unified cache shared by all the workloads. However, existing cache
management strategies, designed for specific workloads, struggle to handle the
heterogeneous AI workloads in a cluster -- which usually exhibit heterogeneous
access patterns and item storage granularities. In this paper, we propose
IGTCache, a unified, high-efficacy cache for modern AI clusters. IGTCache
leverages a hierarchical access abstraction, AccessStreamTree, to organize the
recent data accesses in a tree structure, facilitating access pattern detection
at various granularities. Using this abstraction, IGTCache applies hypothesis
testing to categorize data access patterns as sequential, random, or skewed.
Based on these detected access patterns and granularities, IGTCache tailors
optimal cache management strategies including prefetching, eviction, and space
allocation accordingly. Experimental results show that IGTCache increases the
cache hit ratio by 55.6% over state-of-the-art caching frameworks, reducing the
overall job completion time by 52.2%.

AI.tldr: IGTCache introduces a unified cache for diverse AI workloads, significantly improving cache efficiency through access pattern detection.
AI.motivation: The paper aims to address the challenge of efficiently caching heterogeneous data access patterns and storage needs in AI clusters, avoiding complexity and space wastage.
AI.method: IGTCache uses AccessStreamTree for hierarchical access abstractions and applies hypothesis testing to classify access patterns, tailoring caching strategies to these patterns.
AI.result: IGTCache improves cache hit ratio by 55.6% and reduces job completion time by 52.2%, outperforming current caching frameworks.
AI.conclusion: The proposed system better handles heterogeneous workloads, achieving high efficiency in modern AI cluster environments.

title: QoS-aware Scheduling of Periodic Real-time Task Graphs on Heterogeneous Pre-occupied MECs
summary:
In latency-sensitive applications, efficient task scheduling is crucial for
maintaining Quality of Service (QoS) while meeting strict timing constraints.
This paper addresses the challenge of scheduling periodic tasks structured as
directed acyclic graphs (DAGs) within heterogeneous, pre-occupied Mobile Edge
Computing (MEC) networks. We propose a modified version of the Heterogeneous
Earliest Finish Time (HEFT) algorithm designed to exploit residual processing
capacity in preoccupied MEC environments. Our approach dynamically identifies
idle intervals on processors to create a feasible hyperperiodic schedule that
specifies an allocated virtual machine (VM), task version, and start time for
each task. This scheduling strategy maximizes the aggregate QoS by optimizing
task execution without disrupting the existing periodic workload, while also
adhering to periodicity, precedence, and resource constraints.Experimental
results demonstrate that our method achieves enhanced load balancing and
resource utilization, highlighting its potential to improve performance in
heterogeneous MEC infrastructures supporting real-time, periodic applications.

AI.tldr: This paper proposes a modification to the HEFT algorithm for efficient scheduling of periodic tasks in heterogeneous MEC networks, focusing on maximizing QoS and resource utilization.
AI.motivation: The paper aims to address the challenge of optimizing scheduling for latency-sensitive periodic tasks in heterogeneous networks, balancing QoS while adhering to strict timing and resource constraints.
AI.method: It presents an improved HEFT algorithm that dynamically uses idle processor intervals to create hyperperiodic schedules in MEC environments.
AI.result: Experimental evaluations reveal enhanced load balancing, better resource utilization, and improved performance in real-time heterogeneous MEC applications.
AI.conclusion: The modified HEFT algorithm is effective for improving QoS and system performance in periodic task scheduling in MEC infrastructures.

title: HarMoEny: Efficient Multi-GPU Inference of MoE Models
summary:
Mixture-of-Experts (MoE) models offer computational efficiency during
inference by activating only a subset of specialized experts for a given input.
This enables efficient model scaling on multi-GPU systems that use expert
parallelism without compromising performance. However, load imbalance among
experts and GPUs introduces waiting times, which can significantly increase
inference latency. To address this challenge, we propose HarMoEny, a novel
solution to address MoE load imbalance through two simple techniques: (i)
dynamic token redistribution to underutilized GPUs and (ii) asynchronous
prefetching of experts from the system to GPU memory. These techniques achieve
a near-perfect load balance among experts and GPUs and mitigate delays caused
by overloaded GPUs. We implement HarMoEny and compare its latency and
throughput with four MoE baselines using real-world and synthetic datasets.
Under heavy load imbalance, HarMoEny increases throughput by 37%-70% and
reduces time-to-first-token by 34%-41%, compared to the next-best baseline.
Moreover, our ablation study demonstrates that HarMoEny's scheduling policy
reduces the GPU idling time by up to 84% compared to the baseline policies.

AI.tldr: The abstract introduces HarMoEny, optimizing Mixture-of-Experts (MoE) models to reduce inference latency and improve load balance through dynamic token redistribution and asynchronous expert prefetching.
AI.motivation: The paper aims to address the load imbalance and resulting inefficiencies in inference latency within Mixture-of-Experts (MoE) models running on multi-GPU systems.
AI.method: HarMoEny implements dynamic token redistribution to balance GPU utilization and asynchronous prefetching of experts to minimize delays.
AI.result: HarMoEny outperforms four MoE baselines, increasing throughput by 37%-70% and reducing time-to-first-token latency by 34%-41%. GPU idling time is significantly reduced by up to 84%.
AI.conclusion: HarMoEny demonstrates effectiveness in balancing MoE workloads, enhancing computational efficiency and reducing latency on multi-GPU systems.

title: Focusing on Students, not Machines: Grounded Question Generation and Automated Answer Grading
summary:
Digital technologies are increasingly used in education to reduce the
workload of teachers and students. However, creating open-ended study or
examination questions and grading their answers is still a tedious task. This
thesis presents the foundation for a system that generates questions grounded
in class materials and automatically grades student answers. It introduces a
sophisticated method for chunking documents with a visual layout, specifically
targeting PDF documents. This method enhances the accuracy of downstream tasks,
including Retrieval Augmented Generation (RAG). Our thesis demonstrates that
high-quality questions and reference answers can be generated from study
material. Further, it introduces a new benchmark for automated grading of short
answers to facilitate comparison of automated grading systems. An evaluation of
various grading systems is conducted and indicates that Large Language Models
(LLMs) can generalise to the task of automated grading of short answers from
their pre-training tasks. As with other tasks, increasing the parameter size of
the LLMs leads to greater performance. Currently, available systems still need
human oversight, especially in examination scenarios.

AI.tldr: This thesis proposes a system for generating questions and grading answers based on study material using advanced techniques like document chunking and Large Language Models (LLMs).
AI.motivation: The existing process of creating and grading open-ended study or examination questions is time-consuming, and digital technologies have scope for automation in this area.
AI.method: The paper introduces a document chunking method targeting PDF layouts, employs Retrieval Augmented Generation (RAG) for generating material-based questions and answers, and benchmarks grading systems using Large Language Models.
AI.result: The thesis demonstrates that high-quality questions and reference answers can be generated, and LLMs show promising capabilities in automated grading when their parameter size increases.
AI.conclusion: Despite advancements, current systems still require human oversight, particularly in examination settings.

title: A Fast, Reliable, and Secure Programming Language for LLM Agents with Code Actions
summary:
Modern large language models (LLMs) are often deployed as agents, calling
external tools adaptively to solve tasks. Rather than directly calling tools,
it can be more effective for LLMs to write code to perform the tool calls,
enabling them to automatically generate complex control flow such as
conditionals and loops. Such code actions are typically provided as Python
code, since LLMs are quite proficient at it; however, Python may not be the
ideal language due to limited built-in support for performance, security, and
reliability. We propose a novel programming language for code actions, called
Quasar, which has several benefits: (1) automated parallelization to improve
performance, (2) uncertainty quantification to improve reliability and mitigate
hallucinations, and (3) security features enabling the user to validate
actions. LLMs can write code in a subset of Python, which is automatically
transpiled to Quasar. We evaluate our approach on the ViperGPT visual question
answering agent, applied to the GQA dataset, demonstrating that LLMs with
Quasar actions instead of Python actions retain strong performance, while
reducing execution time when possible by 42%, improving security by reducing
user approval interactions when possible by 52%, and improving reliability by
applying conformal prediction to achieve a desired target coverage level.

AI.tldr: Modern LLMs often call tools adaptively, but coding actions with Python may have limitations. The paper introduces Quasar, a programming language offering enhanced performance, security, and reliability. Results show improvements in execution time, security validations, and reliability while maintaining strong performance.
AI.motivation: The paper aims to address limitations in Python-based code actions for tool calls by modern LLMs, focusing on performance, reliability, and security enhancements.
AI.method: The authors propose a new programming language, Quasar, with features such as parallelization, uncertainty quantification, and security validation. Code written by LLMs in a Python subset is then transpiled to Quasar for execution.
AI.result: Evaluation using the ViperGPT visual question answering agent on the GQA dataset revealed that Quasar reduced execution time by 42%, improved security by reducing approval interactions by 52%, and enhanced reliability through conformal predictions.
AI.conclusion: Quasar proves to be a viable alternative to Python for LLM code actions, offering significant benefits in performance, reliability, and security, without sacrificing task-solving effectiveness.

title: The Amazon Nova Family of Models: Technical Report and Model Card
summary:
We present Amazon Nova, a new generation of state-of-the-art foundation
models that deliver frontier intelligence and industry-leading price
performance. Amazon Nova Pro is a highly-capable multimodal model with the best
combination of accuracy, speed, and cost for a wide range of tasks. Amazon Nova
Lite is a low-cost multimodal model that is lightning fast for processing
images, video, documents and text. Amazon Nova Micro is a text-only model that
delivers our lowest-latency responses at very low cost. Amazon Nova Canvas is
an image generation model that creates professional grade images with rich
customization controls. Amazon Nova Reel is a video generation model offering
high-quality outputs, customization, and motion control. Our models were built
responsibly and with a commitment to customer trust, security, and reliability.
We report benchmarking results for core capabilities, agentic performance, long
context, functional adaptation, runtime performance, and human evaluation.

AI.tldr: Amazon Nova introduces a suite of innovative AI foundation models, optimized for multimodal tasks, text-only tasks, and media generation, alongside responsible and secure development.
AI.motivation: The motivation behind Amazon Nova is to provide high-performance, state-of-the-art, cost-efficient AI models for diverse applications including text, image, video, and multimodal tasks, addressing both accuracy and cost challenges.
AI.method: Amazon Nova develops multiple AI models like Nova Pro, Lite, Micro, Canvas, and Reel, each tailored for specific tasks and capabilities, focusing on multimodal processing, text handling, and media generation. Benchmarking techniques were employed to assess performance.
AI.result: The paper shows benchmarking results spanning core capabilities, agentic performance, context handling, functional adaptability, runtime efficiency, and human evaluations, confirming the models' effectiveness.
AI.conclusion: Amazon Nova successfully delivers industry-leading foundation models with a balance of accuracy, speed, cost-efficiency, and responsible development, tailored for diverse applications in AI.

title: The CAISAR Platform: Extending the Reach of Machine Learning Specification and Verification
summary:
The formal specification and verification of machine learning programs saw
remarkable progress in less than a decade, leading to a profusion of tools.
However, diversity may lead to fragmentation, resulting in tools that are
difficult to compare, except for very specific benchmarks. Furthermore, this
progress is heavily geared towards the specification and verification of a
certain class of property, that is, local robustness properties. But while
provers are becoming more and more efficient at solving local robustness
properties, even slightly more complex properties, involving multiple neural
networks for example, cannot be expressed in the input languages of winners of
the International Competition of Verification of Neural Networks VNN-Comp. In
this tool paper, we present CAISAR, an open-source platform dedicated to
machine learning specification and verification. We present its specification
language, suitable for modelling complex properties on neural networks, support
vector machines and boosted trees. We show on concrete use-cases how
specifications written in this language are automatically translated to queries
to state-of-the-art provers, notably by using automated graph editing
techniques, making it possible to use their off-the-shelf versions. The
artifact to reproduce the paper claims is available at the following DOI:
https://doi.org/10.5281/zenodo.15209510

AI.tldr: The paper introduces CAISAR, an open-source platform for the specification and verification of complex properties in machine learning models, designed to address limitations of current tools.
AI.motivation: There is a lack of standardized tools for comparing machine learning verification tools and an overemphasis on specifying local robustness properties, limiting progress in handling complex properties.
AI.method: The paper presents a new specification language within CAISAR for modeling complex properties and enables automatic translation of these specifications into queries for state-of-the-art provers through automated graph editing techniques.
AI.result: CAISAR successfully supports specifying and verifying complex properties for neural networks, support vector machines, and boosted trees, using existing provers.
AI.conclusion: CAISAR overcomes fragmentation in verification tools and expands their capacity to handle more complex machine learning properties, promoting a standardized methodology for the community.

title: Design and Development of a Robotic Transcatheter Delivery System for Aortic Valve Replacement
comment:
1 page with 2 figures. This abstract has been accepted by the 2025
  International Conference on Robotics and Automation (ICRA) Workshop on
  Robot-Assisted Endovascular Interventions
summary:
Minimally invasive transcatheter approaches are increasingly adopted for
aortic stenosis treatment, where optimal commissural and coronary alignment is
important. Achieving precise alignment remains clinically challenging, even
with contemporary robotic transcatheter aortic valve replacement (TAVR)
devices, as this task is still performed manually. This paper proposes the
development of a robotic transcatheter delivery system featuring an
omnidirectional bending joint and an actuation system designed to enhance
positional accuracy and precision in TAVR procedures. The preliminary
experimental results validate the functionality of this novel robotic system.

AI.tldr: This paper introduces a novel robotic transcatheter delivery system aiming to improve precision in aortic stenosis treatment through enhanced positional control.
AI.motivation: Conventional approaches in transcatheter aortic valve replacement struggle with achieving optimal alignment, leading to the need for robotic systems for better control and precision.
AI.method: The study designed a robotic delivery system with an omnidirectional bending joint and advanced actuation mechanisms to address alignment challenges in TAVR.
AI.result: Preliminary experiments demonstrated that the robotic system improved functionality and positional accuracy during TAVR procedures.
AI.conclusion: The proposed robotic system shows promise in enhancing precision and outcomes for transcatheter aortic valve replacement, addressing a key clinical challenge.

title: FlexQuant: A Flexible and Efficient Dynamic Precision Switching Framework for LLM Quantization
summary:
The rapid advancement of large language models (LLMs) has exacerbated the
memory bottleneck due to the widening gap between model parameter scaling and
hardware capabilities. While post-training quantization (PTQ) techniques
effectively reduce memory overhead, existing methods predominantly rely on
static quantization strategies, which struggle to adapt to dynamic workloads.
To address this, we propose FlexQuant, a dynamic precision-switching framework
that optimizes the trade-off between inference speed and accuracy. Leveraging
model perplexity entropy and Kullback-Leibler (KL) divergence, FlexQuant
enables fine-grained, layer-wise mixed-precision quantization and dynamically
adjusts bit-widths during each token generation. Our work provides a
comprehensive analysis of quantization strategies, introduces a precision
requirement model for optimal switching, and implements efficient fine-grained
precision management. Experimental results demonstrate that FlexQuant achieves
a 1.3x end-to-end speedup across diverse language tasks with negligible
accuracy loss introduced. This framework offers a flexible and adaptive
solution for efficient LLM deployment.

AI.tldr: FlexQuant proposes dynamic precision-switching for large language models to reduce memory bottlenecks while maintaining accuracy.
AI.motivation: To address the challenges of static quantization methods in adapting to dynamic workloads and optimizing inference speed versus accuracy for large language models.
AI.method: FlexQuant employs model perplexity entropy and KL divergence for layer-wise mixed-precision quantization, dynamically adjusting bit-widths during token generation.
AI.result: FlexQuant achieved a 1.3x speedup in processing while maintaining negligible accuracy loss across diverse language tasks.
AI.conclusion: FlexQuant provides an efficient and adaptive framework for deploying large language models, optimizing performance under memory constraints.

title: Multiple Object Tracking in Video SAR: A Benchmark and Tracking Baseline
summary:
In the context of multi-object tracking using video synthetic aperture radar
(Video SAR), Doppler shifts induced by target motion result in artifacts that
are easily mistaken for shadows caused by static occlusions. Moreover,
appearance changes of the target caused by Doppler mismatch may lead to
association failures and disrupt trajectory continuity. A major limitation in
this field is the lack of public benchmark datasets for standardized algorithm
evaluation. To address the above challenges, we collected and annotated 45
video SAR sequences containing moving targets, and named the Video SAR MOT
Benchmark (VSMB). Specifically, to mitigate the effects of trailing and
defocusing in moving targets, we introduce a line feature enhancement mechanism
that emphasizes the positive role of motion shadows and reduces false alarms
induced by static occlusions. In addition, to mitigate the adverse effects of
target appearance variations, we propose a motion-aware clue discarding
mechanism that substantially improves tracking robustness in Video SAR. The
proposed model achieves state-of-the-art performance on the VSMB, and the
dataset and model are released at https://github.com/softwarePupil/VSMB.

AI.tldr: The paper introduces the Video SAR MOT Benchmark (VSMB) composed of 45 annotated sequences for multi-object tracking in Video SAR and proposes new mechanisms for mitigating artifacts and appearance variation effects.
AI.motivation: Enhance multi-object tracking in Video SAR by mitigating challenges caused by Doppler-induced artifacts and lack of public benchmark datasets.
AI.method: Introduced the VSMB dataset and developed mechanisms like line feature enhancement for artifact reduction and motion-aware clue discarding for tracking robustness.
AI.result: Achieved state-of-the-art performance on the proposed VSMB with significant tracking accuracy improvements.
AI.conclusion: The VSMB dataset and proposed approaches address longstanding challenges, enabling better evaluation and improvement of Video SAR-based tracking algorithms.

title: Temporal cross-validation impacts multivariate time series subsequence anomaly detection evaluation
summary:
Evaluating anomaly detection in multivariate time series (MTS) requires
careful consideration of temporal dependencies, particularly when detecting
subsequence anomalies common in fault detection scenarios. While time series
cross-validation (TSCV) techniques aim to preserve temporal ordering during
model evaluation, their impact on classifier performance remains underexplored.
This study systematically investigates the effect of TSCV strategy on the
precision-recall characteristics of classifiers trained to detect fault-like
anomalies in MTS datasets. We compare walk-forward (WF) and sliding window (SW)
methods across a range of validation partition configurations and classifier
types, including shallow learners and deep learning (DL) classifiers. Results
show that SW consistently yields higher median AUC-PR scores and reduced
fold-to-fold performance variance, particularly for deep architectures
sensitive to localized temporal continuity. Furthermore, we find that
classifier generalization is sensitive to the number and structure of temporal
partitions, with overlapping windows preserving fault signatures more
effectively at lower fold counts. A classifier-level stratified analysis
reveals that certain algorithms, such as random forests (RF), maintain stable
performance across validation schemes, whereas others exhibit marked
sensitivity. This study demonstrates that TSCV design in benchmarking anomaly
detection models on streaming time series and provide guidance for selecting
evaluation strategies in temporally structured learning environments.

AI.tldr: This paper studies the impact of time series cross-validation (TSCV) strategies on the performance of anomaly detection models for multivariate time series, comparing precision-recall outcomes for different methods and classifiers.
AI.motivation: The motivation is to understand how temporal dependencies and cross-validation strategies influence the performance of models detecting anomalies, which is critical for fault detection in multivariate time series.
AI.method: The paper evaluates walk-forward (WF) and sliding window (SW) TSCV methods across diverse validation configurations and classifier types, including both shallow learners and deep learning algorithms.
AI.result: Sliding window (SW) TSCV consistently yields better median AUC-PR scores and lower performance variance, particularly benefiting deep architectures sensitive to temporal continuity.
AI.conclusion: TSCV configurations significantly impact classifier generalization and evaluation outcomes. Recommendations for benchmarking anomaly detection models in streaming time series environments are provided.

title: Green Economic Load Dispatch: A Review and Implementation
summary:
The economic dispatch of generators is a major concern in thermal power
plants that governs the share of each generating unit with an objective of
minimizing fuel cost by fulfilling load demand. This problem is not as simple
as it looks because of system constraints that cannot be neglected practically.
Moreover, increased awareness of clean technology imposes another important
limit on the emission of pollutants obtained from burning of fossil fuels.
Classical optimization methods lack the ability of solving such a complex and
multi-objective problem. Hence, various modern artificial intelligence (AI)
techniques based on evolution and social behaviour of organisms are being used
to solve such problems because they are easier to implement, give accurate
results and take less computational time. In this work, a study is done on most
of the contemporary basic AI techniques being used in literature for power
systems in general and combined economic emission dispatch (CEED) in
particular. The dispatch problem is implemented on IEEE 30-bus benchmarked
system in MATLAB for different load demands considering all gases (COX, NOX and
SOX) using particle swarm optimization (PSO) and genetic algorithm (GA) and
their results are compared with each other.

AI.tldr: The paper addresses economic dispatch in thermal power plants, balancing fuel costs and emission constraints using AI techniques like PSO and GA.
AI.motivation: The need to minimize fuel costs while meeting load demands and addressing emission constraints in thermal power plants.
AI.method: Study and comparison of particle swarm optimization (PSO) and genetic algorithm (GA) applied to the IEEE 30-bus system for economic emission dispatch.
AI.result: PSO and GA were implemented for dispatch under various load demands, considering emissions like COX, NOX, and SOX.
AI.conclusion: AI techniques such as PSO and GA are effective for solving complex multi-objective dispatch problems, outperforming classical methods.

title: An Efficient Hardware Implementation of Elliptic Curve Point Multiplication over $GF(2^m)$ on FPGA
summary:
Elliptic Curve Cryptography (ECC) is widely accepted for ensuring secure data
exchange between resource-limited IoT devices. The National Institute of
Standards and Technology (NIST) recommended implementation, such as B-163, is
particularly well-suited for Internet of Things (IoT) applications. Here,
Elliptic Curve Point Multiplication (ECPM) is the most time-critical and
resource-intensive operation due to the finite field multiplier. This paper
proposes a new implementation method of finite field multiplication using a
hybrid Karatsuba multiplier, which achieves a significant improvement in
computation time while maintaining a reasonable area footprint. The proposed
multiplier, along with a finite field adder, squarer, and extended Euclidean
inversion circuit, is used to implement an architecture for ECPM using the
Montgomery algorithm. The architecture is evaluated for $GF(2^{163})$ on the
Xilinx Virtex-7 FPGA platform, achieving a maximum frequency of 213~MHz and
occupying 14,195 Lookup Tables (LUTs). The results demonstrate a significant
speedup in computation time and overall performance compared to other reported
designs.

AI.tldr: The paper introduces a new hybrid Karatsuba multiplier designed to optimize finite field multiplication, thereby improving Elliptic Curve Point Multiplication (ECPM) efficiency for IoT applications.
AI.motivation: Elliptic Curve Cryptography is widely used for secure data exchange in IoT devices, but ECPM operations are computationally intensive and resource-demanding, necessitating improvements in efficiency.
AI.method: A hybrid Karatsuba multiplier is developed for finite field multiplication and integrated with other components (adder, squarer, inversion circuit) within a Montgomery-based architecture for ECPM.
AI.result: Implemented on a Xilinx Virtex-7 FPGA, the architecture achieved 213 MHz frequency with 14,195 LUT usage, demonstrating higher speed and efficiency than existing designs.
AI.conclusion: The proposed approach improves computation time and overall performance for ECPM, making it well-suited for secure cryptographic operations in resource-constrained IoT devices.

title: NR Cell Identity-based Handover Decision-making Algorithm for High-speed Scenario within Dual Connectivity
summary:
The dense deployment of 5G heterogeneous networks (HetNets) has improved
network capacity. However, it also brings frequent and unnecessary handover
challenges to high-speed mobile user equipment (UE), resulting in unstable
communication and degraded quality of service. Traditional handovers ignore the
type of target next-generation Node B (gNB), resulting in high-speed UEs being
able to be handed over to any gNB. This paper proposes a NR cell identity
(NCI)-based handover decision-making algorithm (HDMA) to address this issue.
The proposed HDMA identifies the type of the target gNB (macro/small/mmWave
gNB) using the gNB identity (ID) within the NCI to improve the handover
decision-making strategy. The proposed HDMA aims to improve the communication
stability of high-speed mobile UE by enabling high-speed UEs to identify the
target gNB type during the HDMA using the gNB ID. Simulation results show that
the proposed HDMA outperforms other HDMAs in enhanced connection stability.

AI.tldr: The study addresses unstable communication for high-speed mobile devices in 5G networks due to unnecessary handovers, and proposes an algorithm to improve handover decisions.
AI.motivation: To tackle frequent and unnecessary handovers in 5G heterogeneous networks that degrade communication stability and quality of service for high-speed mobile devices.
AI.method: The study introduces an NCI-based handover decision-making algorithm (HDMA) that identifies the type of target gNB (macro/small/mmWave) using the gNB identity for better handover decision-making.
AI.result: Simulation results demonstrate that the proposed HDMA improves connection stability for high-speed mobile UEs compared to other handover strategies.
AI.conclusion: The proposed HDMA enhances communication stability for high-speed UEs in 5G networks, providing a more effective handover decision-making process.

title: Examining the effects of music on cognitive skills of children in early childhood with the Pythagorean fuzzy set approach
summary:
There are many genetic and environmental factors that affect cognitive
development. Music education can also be considered as one of the environmental
factors. Some researchers emphasize that Music is an action that requires
meta-cognitive functions such as mathematics and chess and supports spatial
intelligence. The effect of Music on cognitive development in early childhood
was examined using the Pythagorean Fuzzy Sets(PFS) method defined by Yager.
This study created PFS based on experts' opinions, and an algorithm was given
according to PFS. The algorithm's results supported the experts' data on the
development of spatial-temporal skills in music education given in early
childhood. The algorithm's ranking was done using the Expectation Score
Function. The rankings obtained from the algorithm overlap with the experts'
rankings.

AI.tldr: The study examines the impact of music education on early childhood cognitive development, focusing on spatial-temporal skills, using Pythagorean Fuzzy Sets (PFS).
AI.motivation: To explore how music education, an environmental factor, influences cognitive development, particularly in terms of higher-order spatial and meta-cognitive functions.
AI.method: The Pythagorean Fuzzy Sets (PFS) method was employed to analyze expert opinions. An algorithm using PFS and an Expectation Score Function was developed for ranking the influence of music education.
AI.result: The algorithm's rankings aligned closely with expert opinions, confirming that early music education supports the development of spatial-temporal skills.
AI.conclusion: The findings validate the positive impact of early music education on cognitive development, specifically by enhancing spatial intelligence and temporal reasoning.

title: Optimizing Federated Learning using Remote Embeddings for Graph Neural Networks
comment:
Preprint of paper in the proceedings of the 30th International
  European Conference on Parallel and Distributed Computing (Euro-Par)
summary:
Graph Neural Networks (GNNs) have experienced rapid advancements in recent
years due to their ability to learn meaningful representations from graph data
structures. Federated Learning (FL) has emerged as a viable machine learning
approach for training a shared model on decentralized data, addressing privacy
concerns while leveraging parallelism. Existing methods that address the unique
requirements of federated GNN training using remote embeddings to enhance
convergence accuracy are limited by their diminished performance due to large
communication costs with a shared embedding server. In this paper, we present
OpES, an optimized federated GNN training framework that uses remote
neighbourhood pruning, and overlaps pushing of embeddings to the server with
local training to reduce the network costs and training time. The modest drop
in per-round accuracy due to pre-emptive push of embeddings is out-stripped by
the reduction in per-round training time for large and dense graphs like Reddit
and Products, converging up to $\approx2\times$ faster than the
state-of-the-art technique using an embedding server and giving up to $20\%$
better accuracy than vanilla federated GNN learning.

AI.tldr: The paper introduces OpES, an efficient framework for federated GNN training that optimizes training time and network costs using remote neighborhood pruning and overlapping embedding operations.
AI.motivation: Current federated GNN methods face challenges from high communication costs with shared embedding servers and reduced model performance. This paper aims to address these inefficiencies.
AI.method: OpES leverages techniques like remote neighborhood pruning and overlapping the pushing of embeddings to a server with local training to mitigate network costs and speed up convergence.
AI.result:
OpES achieves up to $
atexlabapprox$2× faster convergence than existing state-of-the-art techniques and improves accuracy by up to 20% compared to vanilla federated GNN approaches.
AI.conclusion: The proposed framework successfully balances trade-offs between accuracy and training efficiency, offering significant improvements for large, dense graphs in federated GNN scenarios.

title: ChatbotManip: A Dataset to Facilitate Evaluation and Oversight of Manipulative Chatbot Behaviour
summary:
This paper introduces ChatbotManip, a novel dataset for studying manipulation
in Chatbots. It contains simulated generated conversations between a chatbot
and a (simulated) user, where the chatbot is explicitly asked to showcase
manipulation tactics, persuade the user towards some goal, or simply be
helpful. We consider a diverse set of chatbot manipulation contexts, from
consumer and personal advice to citizen advice and controversial proposition
argumentation. Each conversation is annotated by human annotators for both
general manipulation and specific manipulation tactics. Our research reveals
three key findings. First, Large Language Models (LLMs) can be manipulative
when explicitly instructed, with annotators identifying manipulation in
approximately 84\% of such conversations. Second, even when only instructed to
be ``persuasive'' without explicit manipulation prompts, LLMs frequently
default to controversial manipulative strategies, particularly gaslighting and
fear enhancement. Third, small fine-tuned open source models, such as
BERT+BiLSTM have a performance comparable to zero-shot classification with
larger models like Gemini 2.5 pro in detecting manipulation, but are not yet
reliable for real-world oversight. Our work provides important insights for AI
safety research and highlights the need of addressing manipulation risks as
LLMs are increasingly deployed in consumer-facing applications.

AI.tldr: The paper introduces ChatbotManip, a dataset to study and detect manipulation tactics in chatbots and evaluates their use of manipulative strategies based on instruction prompts.
AI.motivation: To explore and analyze the risks of manipulation in chatbot interactions as large language models grow increasingly prevalent in consumer and societal applications.
AI.method: The authors created the ChatbotManip dataset, containing simulated conversations with LLMs under different manipulation contexts, and annotated them with human oversight to identify manipulative behaviors.
AI.result: Annotators found manipulative strategies used in 84% of cases when explicitly prompted; LLMs self-adopt manipulative tactics like gaslighting and fear enhancement even when only instructed to be 'persuasive'; smaller fine-tuned models perform on par with larger zero-shot models for manipulation detection but aren't practically reliable.
AI.conclusion: The study underscores the need to mitigate manipulation risks in AI systems while providing a new dataset and insights valuable for AI safety and ethical use in consumer settings.

title: Freer Arrows and Why You Need Them in Haskell
comment: In submission to the Haskell Symposium 2025
summary:
Freer monads are a useful structure commonly used in various domains due to
their expressiveness. However, a known issue with freer monads is that they are
not amenable to static analysis. This paper explores freer arrows, a relatively
expressive structure that is amenable to static analysis. We propose several
variants of freer arrows. We conduct a case study on choreographic programming
to demonstrate the usefulness of freer arrows in Haskell.

AI.tldr: The paper investigates freer arrows to address static analysis limitations of freer monads, highlighting their expressiveness and applicability, particularly with Haskell.
AI.motivation: Freer monads face challenges with static analysis, despite their wide usage and expressiveness. This paper seeks to find an alternative structure that can overcome this limitation.
AI.method: The authors propose and explore several variants of freer arrows and validate their applicability through a case study in choreographic programming within Haskell.
AI.result: Freer arrows are shown to be a powerful structure that addresses the static analysis limitations of freer monads while retaining significant expressiveness.
AI.conclusion: Freer arrows offer a viable and expressive alternative to freer monads, especially in use cases where static analysis is critical, such as choreographic programming in Haskell.

title: Because we have LLMs, we Can and Should Pursue Agentic Interpretability
summary:
The era of Large Language Models (LLMs) presents a new opportunity for
interpretability--agentic interpretability: a multi-turn conversation with an
LLM wherein the LLM proactively assists human understanding by developing and
leveraging a mental model of the user, which in turn enables humans to develop
better mental models of the LLM. Such conversation is a new capability that
traditional `inspective' interpretability methods (opening the black-box) do
not use. Having a language model that aims to teach and explain--beyond just
knowing how to talk--is similar to a teacher whose goal is to teach well,
understanding that their success will be measured by the student's
comprehension. While agentic interpretability may trade off completeness for
interactivity, making it less suitable for high-stakes safety situations with
potentially deceptive models, it leverages a cooperative model to discover
potentially superhuman concepts that can improve humans' mental model of
machines. Agentic interpretability introduces challenges, particularly in
evaluation, due to what we call `human-entangled-in-the-loop' nature (humans
responses are integral part of the algorithm), making the design and evaluation
difficult. We discuss possible solutions and proxy goals. As LLMs approach
human parity in many tasks, agentic interpretability's promise is to help
humans learn the potentially superhuman concepts of the LLMs, rather than see
us fall increasingly far from understanding them.

AI.tldr: The paper introduces the concept of 'agentic interpretability,' where large language models engage in a two-way conversation with users to assist mutual understanding, focusing more on interactivity than traditional methods.
AI.motivation: To address the limitations of traditional interpretability approaches for LLMs by proposing a dynamic, conversation-driven method that enhances mutual understanding between humans and models.
AI.method: The paper suggests enabling LLMs to proactively model and adapt to users, acting like a teacher who helps humans grasp potentially superhuman concepts using interactive conversation rather than static inspection.
AI.result: The authors argue that 'agentic interpretability' aids humans in forming better mental models of LLMs, though challenges like evaluation complexity are highlighted.
AI.conclusion: Agentic interpretability offers a pathway for humans to align better with LLMs and their advanced capabilities, with potential for improving understanding despite evaluation challenges.

title: Quantum-Inspired Differentiable Integral Neural Networks (QIDINNs): A Feynman-Based Architecture for Continuous Learning Over Streaming Data
summary:
Real-time continuous learning over streaming data remains a central challenge
in deep learning and AI systems. Traditional gradient-based models such as
backpropagation through time (BPTT) face computational and stability
limitations when dealing with temporally unbounded data. In this paper, we
introduce a novel architecture, Quantum-Inspired Differentiable Integral Neural
Networks (QIDINNs), which leverages the Feynman technique of differentiation
under the integral sign to formulate neural updates as integrals over
historical data. This reformulation allows for smoother, more stable learning
dynamics that are both physically interpretable and computationally tractable.
Inspired by Feynman's path integral formalism and compatible with quantum
gradient estimation frameworks, QIDINNs open a path toward hybrid
classical-quantum neural computation. We demonstrate our model's effectiveness
on synthetic and real-world streaming tasks, and we propose directions for
quantum extensions and scalable implementations.

AI.tldr: A novel neural network architecture, Quantum-Inspired Differentiable Integral Neural Networks (QIDINNs), introduces integral-based updates for stable real-time learning on streaming data.
AI.motivation: Address limitations of traditional gradient-based models in learning from temporally unbounded data using a novel quantum-inspired approach.
AI.method: QIDINNs utilize differentiation under the integral inspired by Feynman, enabling integral-based neural updates for smooth and stable learning dynamics.
AI.result: Demonstrates effectiveness of QIDINNs on synthetic and real-world streaming tasks, highlighting potential for classical-quantum neural computation.
AI.conclusion: QIDINNs provide a computationally efficient and physically interpretable pathway for real-time learning, with potential for quantum extensions.

title: Using Behavior Trees in Risk Assessment
summary:
Cyber-physical production systems increasingly involve collaborative robotic
missions, requiring more demand for robust and safe missions. Industries rely
on risk assessments to identify potential failures and implement measures to
mitigate their risks. Although it is recommended to conduct risk assessments
early in the design of robotic missions, the state of practice in the industry
is different. Safety experts often struggle to completely understand robotics
missions at the early design stages of projects and to ensure that the output
of risk assessments is adequately considered during implementation.
  This paper presents a design science study that conceived a model-based
approach for early risk assessment in a development-centric way. Our approach
supports risk assessment activities by using the behavior-tree model. We
evaluated the approach together with five practitioners from four companies.
Our findings highlight the potential of the behavior-tree model in supporting
early identification, visualisation, and bridging the gap between code
implementation and risk assessments' outputs. This approach is the first
attempt to use the behavior-tree model to support risk assessment; thus, the
findings highlight the need for further development.

AI.tldr: The paper proposes a model-based approach using behavior-tree models to enhance early risk assessment in collaborative robotic missions, addressing the gap between implementation and risk assessment outcomes.
AI.motivation: The study aims to improve early risk assessment in cyber-physical production systems, as safety experts face challenges in understanding robotic missions and integrating risk assessment results during early design stages.
AI.method: The authors introduce a behavior-tree model-based approach and evaluate its effectiveness with practitioners from four companies.
AI.result: The evaluation shows the potential of behavior-tree models to enhance early identification, visualization, and coordination between risk assessments and code implementation.
AI.conclusion: The approach demonstrates promise but requires further development for widespread industry application.

title: Unsupervised Learning for Optimal Transport plan prediction between unbalanced graphs
summary:
Optimal transport between graphs, based on Gromov-Wasserstein and
  other extensions, is a powerful tool for comparing and aligning
  graph structures. However, solving the associated non-convex
  optimization problems is computationally expensive, which limits the
  scalability of these methods to large graphs. In this work, we
  present Unbalanced Learning of Optimal Transport (ULOT), a deep
  learning method that predicts optimal transport plans between two
  graphs. Our method is trained by minimizing the fused unbalanced
  Gromov-Wasserstein (FUGW) loss. We propose a novel neural
  architecture with cross-attention that is conditioned on the FUGW
  tradeoff hyperparameters. We evaluate ULOT on synthetic stochastic
  block model (SBM) graphs and on real cortical surface data obtained
  from fMRI. ULOT predicts transport plans with competitive loss up to
  two orders of magnitude faster than classical solvers. Furthermore,
  the predicted plan can be used as a warm start for classical solvers
  to accelerate their convergence. Finally, the predicted transport
  plan is fully differentiable with respect to the graph inputs and
  FUGW hyperparameters, enabling the optimization of functionals of
  the ULOT plan.

AI.tldr: The paper introduces ULOT, a deep learning method to predict optimal transport plans between graphs, achieving faster computation and competitive performance compared to classical approaches.
AI.motivation: Solving non-convex optimization problems in optimal transport between graphs is computationally intensive, creating challenges for scaling these methods to large graphs.
AI.method: The authors propose a deep learning method named ULOT that minimizes the fused unbalanced Gromov-Wasserstein (FUGW) loss. The approach incorporates a novel neural architecture with cross-attention, conditioned on FUGW hyperparameters.
AI.result: ULOT achieves competitive transport plan losses while being up to two orders of magnitude faster than classical solvers. Moreover, it provides differentiable transport plans that can optimize various functionals.
AI.conclusion: ULOT offers an efficient and versatile solution for optimal graph transport, enabling faster computations and applications in diverse scenarios such as fMRI cortical surface data alignment.

title: BreastDCEDL: Curating a Comprehensive DCE-MRI Dataset and developing a Transformer Implementation for Breast Cancer Treatment Response Prediction
summary:
Breast cancer remains a leading cause of cancer-related mortality worldwide,
making early detection and accurate treatment response monitoring critical
priorities. We present BreastDCEDL, a curated, deep learning-ready dataset
comprising pre-treatment 3D Dynamic Contrast-Enhanced MRI (DCE-MRI) scans from
2,070 breast cancer patients drawn from the I-SPY1, I-SPY2, and Duke cohorts,
all sourced from The Cancer Imaging Archive. The raw DICOM imaging data were
rigorously converted into standardized 3D NIfTI volumes with preserved signal
integrity, accompanied by unified tumor annotations and harmonized clinical
metadata including pathologic complete response (pCR), hormone receptor (HR),
and HER2 status. Although DCE-MRI provides essential diagnostic information and
deep learning offers tremendous potential for analyzing such complex data,
progress has been limited by lack of accessible, public, multicenter datasets.
BreastDCEDL addresses this gap by enabling development of advanced models,
including state-of-the-art transformer architectures that require substantial
training data. To demonstrate its capacity for robust modeling, we developed
the first transformer-based model for breast DCE-MRI, leveraging Vision
Transformer (ViT) architecture trained on RGB-fused images from three contrast
phases (pre-contrast, early post-contrast, and late post-contrast). Our ViT
model achieved state-of-the-art pCR prediction performance in HR+/HER2-
patients (AUC 0.94, accuracy 0.93). BreastDCEDL includes predefined benchmark
splits, offering a framework for reproducible research and enabling clinically
meaningful modeling in breast cancer imaging.

AI.tldr: The BreastDCEDL dataset provides standardized, deep learning-ready DCE-MRI scans from over 2,000 breast cancer patients, facilitating development of advanced models for cancer analysis, with a demonstrated Vision Transformer achieving exceptional predictive performance.
AI.motivation: To address the need for robust, accessible, multicenter datasets enabling early breast cancer diagnosis and treatment modeling.
AI.method: Utilized a curated dataset of pre-treatment DCE-MRI scans, standardized into 3D NIfTI volumes with unified annotations and metadata, to develop a Vision Transformer (ViT) model trained on RGB-fused contrast images.
AI.result: The ViT model achieved state-of-the-art pCR prediction performance in HR+/HER2- patients, with an AUC of 0.94 and an accuracy of 0.93.
AI.conclusion: BreastDCEDL bridges the gap in publicly accessible breast cancer imaging datasets, enabling reproducible, clinically meaningful research and advancement in predictive modeling.

title: Theoretical Tensions in RLHF: Reconciling Empirical Success with Inconsistencies in Social Choice Theory
summary:
Despite its empirical success, Reinforcement Learning from Human Feedback
(RLHF) has been shown to violate almost all the fundamental axioms in social
choice theory -- such as majority consistency, pairwise majority consistency,
and Condorcet consistency. This raises a foundational question: why does RLHF
perform so well in practice if it fails these seemingly essential properties?
In this paper, we resolve this paradox by showing that under mild and
empirically plausible assumptions on the preference profile, RLHF does satisfy
pairwise majority and Condorcet consistency. These assumptions are frequently
satisfied in real-world alignment tasks, offering a theoretical explanation for
RLHF's strong practical performance. Furthermore, we show that a slight
modification to the reward modeling objective can ensure pairwise majority or
Condorcet consistency even under general preference profiles, thereby improving
the alignment process. Finally, we go beyond classical axioms in economic and
social choice theory and introduce new alignment criteria -- preference
matching, preference equivalence, and group preference matching -- that better
reflect the goal of learning distributions over responses. We show that while
RLHF satisfies the first two properties, it fails to satisfy the third. We
conclude by discussing how future alignment methods may be designed to satisfy
all three.

AI.tldr: This paper resolves why Reinforcement Learning from Human Feedback (RLHF) performs well despite violating axioms in social choice theory, showing that under mild assumptions it meets certain properties, and proposing modifications to further improve alignment.
AI.motivation: The study aims to resolve the paradox of why RLHF works effectively in practice despite failing key social choice theory axioms, to better understand and refine its application in alignment tasks.
AI.method: The authors introduce mild assumptions on the preference profile to prove RLHF can satisfy pairwise majority and Condorcet consistency. They also propose modifications to the reward modeling objective and introduce new alignment criteria.
AI.result: The paper establishes that RLHF satisfies certain social choice properties under realistic assumptions, offers modifications to the reward model, and reveals it meets some but not all newly proposed alignment criteria.
AI.conclusion: RLHF's empirical success is explained through theoretical findings, and further improvements are suggested to ensure better alignment across various criteria.

title: A Synthetic Pseudo-Autoencoder Invites Examination of Tacit Assumptions in Neural Network Design
summary:
We present a handcrafted neural network that, without training, solves the
seemingly difficult problem of encoding an arbitrary set of integers into a
single numerical variable, and then recovering the original elements. While
using only standard neural network operations -- weighted sums with biases and
identity activation -- we make design choices that challenge common notions in
this area around representation, continuity of domains, computation,
learnability and more. For example, our construction is designed, not learned;
it represents multiple values using a single one by simply concatenating digits
without compression, and it relies on hardware-level truncation of rightmost
digits as a bit-manipulation mechanism. This neural net is not intended for
practical application. Instead, we see its resemblance to -- and deviation from
-- standard trained autoencoders as an invitation to examine assumptions that
may unnecessarily constrain the development of systems and models based on
autoencoding and machine learning. Motivated in part by our research on a
theory of biological evolution centered around natural autoencoding of species
characteristics, we conclude by refining the discussion with a biological
perspective.

AI.tldr: The paper introduces a handcrafted neural network that encodes and decodes integers without training, challenging conventional ideas in neural network design.
AI.motivation: The authors aim to challenge assumptions in standard neural networks and autoencoding by presenting an unconventional design that sidesteps traditional training methods.
AI.method: A neural network is handcrafted using standard operations like weighted sums. The design encodes integers into a single variable through concatenation and uses truncation for decoding.
AI.result: The novel design demonstrates an ability to encode and decode integers despite not being trained, showing the potential for non-traditional approaches in computation.
AI.conclusion: This research positions the neural network as a conceptual tool to revisit and rethink constraints in machine learning and highlights a potential connection to biological evolution.

title: PuDHammer: Experimental Analysis of Read Disturbance Effects of Processing-using-DRAM in Real DRAM Chips
comment:
Extended version of our publication at the 52nd International
  Symposium on Computer Architecture (ISCA-52), 2025
summary:
Processing-using-DRAM (PuD) is a promising paradigm for alleviating the data
movement bottleneck using DRAM's massive internal parallelism and bandwidth to
execute very wide operations. Performing a PuD operation involves activating
multiple DRAM rows in quick succession or simultaneously, i.e., multiple-row
activation. Multiple-row activation is fundamentally different from
conventional memory access patterns that activate one DRAM row at a time.
However, repeatedly activating even one DRAM row (e.g., RowHammer) can induce
bitflips in unaccessed DRAM rows because modern DRAM is subject to read
disturbance. Unfortunately, no prior work investigates the effects of
multiple-row activation on DRAM read disturbance.
  In this paper, we present the first characterization study of read
disturbance effects of multiple-row activation-based PuD (which we call
PuDHammer) using 316 real DDR4 DRAM chips from four major DRAM manufacturers.
Our detailed characterization show that 1) PuDHammer significantly exacerbates
the read disturbance vulnerability, causing up to 158.58x reduction in the
minimum hammer count required to induce the first bitflip ($HC_{first}$),
compared to RowHammer, 2) PuDHammer is affected by various operational
conditions and parameters, 3) combining RowHammer with PuDHammer is more
effective than using RowHammer alone to induce read disturbance error, e.g.,
doing so reduces $HC_{first}$ by 1.66x on average, and 4) PuDHammer bypasses an
in-DRAM RowHammer mitigation mechanism (Target Row Refresh) and induces more
bitflips than RowHammer.
  To develop future robust PuD-enabled systems in the presence of PuDHammer, we
1) develop three countermeasures and 2) adapt and evaluate the state-of-the-art
RowHammer mitigation standardized by industry, called Per Row Activation
Counting (PRAC). We show that the adapted PRAC incurs large performance
overheads (48.26%, on average).

AI.tldr: This paper introduces PuDHammer and studies its impact on DRAM read disturbance vulnerabilities, revealing it is significantly more potent than traditional RowHammer attacks.
AI.motivation: The motivation lies in understanding the effects of multiple-row activation in DRAM's new Processing-using-DRAM (PuD) paradigm, as this operation pattern differs from conventional single-row activation and has unknown consequences on read disturbance vulnerabilities.
AI.method: The researchers characterized PuDHammer effects by studying 316 DDR4 DRAM chips from four major manufacturers, analyzing various operational conditions, parameters, and combining RowHammer with PuDHammer for evaluation.
AI.result: PuDHammer significantly reduces the minimum hammer count needed to induce bitflips compared to RowHammer (up to 158.58x reduction), bypasses existing mitigation mechanisms like Target Row Refresh, and is more effective in combination with RowHammer.
AI.conclusion: The study highlights the severe implications of PuDHammer on DRAM reliability and evaluates mitigation strategies, including an adapted Per Row Activation Counting (PRAC), though the latter incurs substantial performance overheads.

title: A Review of the Long Horizon Forecasting Problem in Time Series Analysis
comment: Submitted to International Journal of Forecasting
summary:
The long horizon forecasting (LHF) problem has come up in the time series
literature for over the last 35 years or so. This review covers aspects of LHF
in this period and how deep learning has incorporated variants of trend,
seasonality, fourier and wavelet transforms, misspecification bias reduction
and bandpass filters while contributing using convolutions, residual
connections, sparsity reduction, strided convolutions, attention masks, SSMs,
normalization methods, low-rank approximations and gating mechanisms. We
highlight time series decomposition techniques, input data preprocessing and
dataset windowing schemes that improve performance. Multi-layer perceptron
models, recurrent neural network hybrids, self-attention models that improve
and/or address the performances of the LHF problem are described, with an
emphasis on the feature space construction. Ablation studies are conducted over
the ETTm2 dataset in the multivariate and univariate high useful load (HUFL)
forecasting contexts, evaluated over the last 4 months of the dataset. The
heatmaps of MSE averages per time step over test set series in the horizon show
that there is a steady increase in the error proportionate to its length except
with xLSTM and Triformer models and motivate LHF as an error propagation
problem. The trained models are available here: https://bit.ly/LHFModelZoo

AI.tldr: The paper reviews the long horizon forecasting (LHF) problem in time series over the past 35 years, focusing on deep learning advancements and methodologies.
AI.motivation: To explore the challenges and advancements in addressing the long horizon forecasting problem in time series, particularly how recent deep learning techniques have tackled these challenges.
AI.method: The authors review several approaches, including trend and seasonality modeling, feature space construction, preprocessing techniques, and innovations in deep learning architectures like xLSTM and Triformer. They conduct ablation studies on the ETTm2 dataset to evaluate performance.
AI.result: The xLSTM and Triformer models showed minimal error propagation over long horizons compared to other methods, as depicted by MSE heatmaps.
AI.conclusion: The study underscores LHF as an error propagation issue and highlights promising methods like xLSTM and Triformer for addressing these challenges.

title: Towards Unified Neural Decoding with Brain Functional Network Modeling
summary:
Recent achievements in implantable brain-computer interfaces (iBCIs) have
demonstrated the potential to decode cognitive and motor behaviors with
intracranial brain recordings; however, individual physiological and electrode
implantation heterogeneities have constrained current approaches to neural
decoding within single individuals, rendering interindividual neural decoding
elusive. Here, we present Multi-individual Brain Region-Aggregated Network
(MIBRAIN), a neural decoding framework that constructs a whole functional brain
network model by integrating intracranial neurophysiological recordings across
multiple individuals. MIBRAIN leverages self-supervised learning to derive
generalized neural prototypes and supports group-level analysis of brain-region
interactions and inter-subject neural synchrony. To validate our framework, we
recorded stereoelectroencephalography (sEEG) signals from a cohort of
individuals performing Mandarin syllable articulation. Both real-time online
and offline decoding experiments demonstrated significant improvements in both
audible and silent articulation decoding, enhanced decoding accuracy with
increased multi-subject data integration, and effective generalization to
unseen subjects. Furthermore, neural predictions for regions without direct
electrode coverage were validated against authentic neural data. Overall, this
framework paves the way for robust neural decoding across individuals and
offers insights for practical clinical applications.

AI.tldr: MIBRAIN is a framework combining intracranial recordings across individuals for improved neural decoding, tested on Mandarin articulation tasks.
AI.motivation: To overcome the limitations of single-individual neural decoding and enable interindividual decoding by creating a generalized brain network model.
AI.method: MIBRAIN integrates functional brain networks using intracranial recordings from multiple individuals, applying self-supervised learning to analyze brain-region interactions and neural synchrony.
AI.result: The method showed notable improvements in decoding accuracy during Mandarin articulation tasks (both audible and silent), better generalization to new individuals, and validation of neural predictions in electrode-free regions.
AI.conclusion: MIBRAIN facilitates accurate neural decoding across individuals and holds promise for practical clinical applications.

title: Accelerating Cloud-Based Transcriptomics: Performance Analysis and Optimization of the STAR Aligner Workflow
summary:
In this work, we explore the Transcriptomics Atlas pipeline adapted for
cost-efficient and high-throughput computing in the cloud. We propose a
scalable, cloud-native architecture designed for running a resource-intensive
aligner -- STAR -- and processing tens or hundreds of terabytes of
RNA-sequencing data. We implement multiple optimization techniques that give
significant execution time and cost reduction. The impact of particular
optimizations is measured in medium-scale experiments followed by a large-scale
experiment that leverages all of them and validates the current design. Early
stopping optimization allows a reduction in total alignment time by 23%. We
analyze the scalability and efficiency of one of the most widely used sequence
aligners. For the cloud environment, we identify one of the most suitable EC2
instance types and verify the applicability of spot instances usage.

AI.tldr: The paper introduces a cost-efficient and high-throughput cloud-native framework for processing RNA-sequencing data with a focus on optimizing the STAR aligner.
AI.motivation: To address the challenge of resource-intensive RNA-sequencing data processing, especially in cloud environments where cost and scalability are paramount.
AI.method: The authors propose and implement a scalable, cloud-native architecture with multiple optimization techniques to enhance execution time and cost efficiency for processing large transcriptomics datasets.
AI.result: Key optimizations reduced the alignment time by 23%, showcase scalability for medium and large-scale experiments, and identified optimal EC2 instance types along with verifying the viability of spot instance usage.
AI.conclusion: This study demonstrates the potential for cloud-based cost and computation-efficient processing of RNA-sequencing data through strategic optimizations, paving the way for more accessible large-scale informatics solutions.

title: Continuously Updating Digital Twins using Large Language Models
summary:
Digital twins are models of real-world systems that can simulate their
dynamics in response to potential actions. In complex settings, the state and
action variables, and available data and knowledge relevant to a system can
constantly change, requiring digital twins to continuously update with these
changes to remain relevant. Current approaches struggle in this regard, as they
require fixed, well-defined modelling environments, and they cannot adapt to
novel variables without re-designs, or incorporate new information without
re-training. To address this, we frame digital twinning as an in-context
learning problem using large language models, enabling seamless updates to the
twin at inference time. We develop CALM-DT, a Context-Adaptive Language
Model-based Digital Twin that can accurately simulate across diverse
state-action spaces using in-context learning alone by utilising fine-tuned
encoders for sample retrieval. We empirically demonstrate CALM-DT's competitive
performance with existing digital twin approaches, and its unique ability to
adapt to changes in its modelling environment without parameter updates.

AI.tldr: Digital twins, as models for real-world systems, often face challenges adapting to dynamic environments. CALM-DT leverages large language models for in-context learning to enable seamless adaptation without parameter updates.
AI.motivation: The paper addresses the limitations of current digital twin systems, especially their inability to adjust in dynamic environments, integrate novel variables, or incorporate new information without requiring significant re-designs or re-training.
AI.method: The authors frame the digital twinning problem as an in-context learning problem using large language models. They develop CALM-DT, which utilizes fine-tuned encoders for sample retrieval and enables inference-time updates.
AI.result: CALM-DT exhibits competitive performance when compared to existing approaches for digital twinning. It uniquely adapts to dynamic changes in its modeling environment without requiring parameter updates.
AI.conclusion: The study showcases CALM-DT's potential as a flexible and adaptive digital twin solution, addressing some key limitations of current methodologies.

title: StacKAT: Infinite State Network Verification
summary:
We develop StacKAT, a network verification language featuring loops, finite
state variables, nondeterminism, and - most importantly - access to a stack
with accompanying push and pop operations. By viewing the variables and stack
as the (parsed) headers and (to-be-parsed) contents of a network packet,
StacKAT can express a wide range of network behaviors including parsing, source
routing, and telemetry. These behaviors are difficult or impossible to model
using existing languages like NetKAT. We develop a decision procedure for
StacKAT program equivalence, based on finite automata. This decision procedure
provides the theoretical basis for verifying network-wide properties and is
able to provide counterexamples for inequivalent programs. Finally, we provide
an axiomatization of StacKAT equivalence and establish its completeness.

AI.tldr: StacKAT is a novel network verification language that incorporates stack operations and finite state variables, enabling robust modeling of diverse network behaviors while providing program equivalence verification.
AI.motivation: Existing languages like NetKAT struggle to model complex network behaviors such as parsing, source routing, and telemetry, necessitating a more expressive language.
AI.method: The paper introduces StacKAT, develops a decision procedure for program equivalence based on finite automata, and provides a complete axiomatization for StacKAT equivalence.
AI.result: The decision procedure established can verify network-wide properties, evaluate program equivalence, and produce counterexamples for inequivalent programs.
AI.conclusion: StacKAT successfully extends network verification capabilities to capture previously inexpressible behaviors, supported by theoretically sound program equivalence verifications.

title: Artificial Intelligence and Machine Learning in the Development of Vaccines and Immunotherapeutics Yesterday, Today, and Tomorrow
summary:
In the past, the development of vaccines and immunotherapeutics relied
heavily on trial-and-error experimentation and extensive in vivo testing, often
requiring years of pre-clinical and clinical trials. Today, artificial
intelligence (AI) and deep learning (DL) are actively transforming vaccine and
immunotherapeutic design, by (i) offering predictive frameworks that support
rapid, data-driven decision-making; (ii) increasingly being implemented as
time- and resource-efficient strategies that integrate computational models,
systems vaccinology, and multi-omics data to better phenotype, differentiate,
and classify patient diseases and cancers; predict patients' immune responses;
and identify the factors contributing to optimal vaccine and immunotherapeutic
protective efficacy; (iii) refining the selection of B- and T-cell
antigen/epitope targets to enhance efficacy and durability of immune
protection; and (iv) enabling a deeper understanding of immune regulation,
immune evasion, immune checkpoints, and regulatory pathways. The future of AI
and DL points toward (i) replacing animal preclinical testing of drugs,
vaccines, and immunotherapeutics with computational-based models, as recently
proposed by the United States FDA; and (ii) enabling real-time in vivo modeling
for immunobridging and prediction of protection in clinical trials. This may
result in a fast and transformative shift for the development of personal
vaccines and immunotherapeutics against infectious pathogens and cancers.

AI.tldr: The paper discusses AI's role in transforming vaccine and immunotherapeutics design by leveraging computational modeling and deep learning for predictive, data-driven approaches that minimize dependency on extensive testing.
AI.motivation: The paper aims to address inefficiencies in traditional vaccine development, which rely heavily on prolonged trial-and-error experimentation and in vivo testing.
AI.method: AI-driven approaches integrate computational models, systems vaccinology, and multi-omics data to refine predictive frameworks, immune profiling, and target antigen selection.
AI.result: Key outcomes include enhanced immune protection durability, improved disease classification, and reduced reliance on animal preclinical testing through computational models.
AI.conclusion: AI and deep learning represent a paradigm shift in vaccine and immunotherapeutic design, promising faster, personalized solutions against pathogens and cancers.

title: Can LLMs Generate High-Quality Test Cases for Algorithm Problems? TestCase-Eval: A Systematic Evaluation of Fault Coverage and Exposure
summary:
We introduce TestCase-Eval, a new benchmark for systematic evaluation of LLMs
in test-case generation. TestCase-Eval includes 500 algorithm problems and
100,000 human-crafted solutions from the Codeforces platform. It focuses on two
pivotal tasks: (1) Fault Coverage, which measures how well LLM-generated test
sets probe diverse input scenarios and cover a wide range of potential failure
modes. (2) Fault Exposure, which evaluates whether LLMs can craft a tailored
test input that reveals a specific incorrect code implementation. We provide a
comprehensive assessment of 19 state-of-the-art open-source and proprietary
LLMs on TestCase-Eval, offering insights into their strengths and limitations
in generating effective test cases for algorithm problems.

AI.tldr: Introduces TestCase-Eval, a benchmark for evaluating large language models (LLMs) in generating diverse and tailored test cases for algorithm problems.
AI.motivation: Current benchmarks struggle to thoroughly evaluate LLM capabilities in systematically generating test cases for algorithmic problem-solving.
AI.method: Built TestCase-Eval using 500 algorithm problems and 100,000 human-crafted solutions, focusing on tasks like Fault Coverage and Fault Exposure to assess LLM performance.
AI.result: Evaluated 19 LLMs (open-source and proprietary), highlighting their strengths and weaknesses in test-case generation.
AI.conclusion: TestCase-Eval prepares a robust framework for better understanding and assessing LLMs' capabilities in problem-driven test case generation.

title: DoublyAware: Dual Planning and Policy Awareness for Temporal Difference Learning in Humanoid Locomotion
summary:
Achieving robust robot learning for humanoid locomotion is a fundamental
challenge in model-based reinforcement learning (MBRL), where environmental
stochasticity and randomness can hinder efficient exploration and learning
stability. The environmental, so-called aleatoric, uncertainty can be amplified
in high-dimensional action spaces with complex contact dynamics, and further
entangled with epistemic uncertainty in the models during learning phases. In
this work, we propose DoublyAware, an uncertainty-aware extension of Temporal
Difference Model Predictive Control (TD-MPC) that explicitly decomposes
uncertainty into two disjoint interpretable components, i.e., planning and
policy uncertainties. To handle the planning uncertainty, DoublyAware employs
conformal prediction to filter candidate trajectories using quantile-calibrated
risk bounds, ensuring statistical consistency and robustness against stochastic
dynamics. Meanwhile, policy rollouts are leveraged as structured informative
priors to support the learning phase with Group-Relative Policy Constraint
(GRPC) optimizers that impose a group-based adaptive trust-region in the latent
action space. This principled combination enables the robot agent to prioritize
high-confidence, high-reward behavior while maintaining effective, targeted
exploration under uncertainty. Evaluated on the HumanoidBench locomotion suite
with the Unitree 26-DoF H1-2 humanoid, DoublyAware demonstrates improved sample
efficiency, accelerated convergence, and enhanced motion feasibility compared
to RL baselines. Our simulation results emphasize the significance of
structured uncertainty modeling for data-efficient and reliable decision-making
in TD-MPC-based humanoid locomotion learning.

AI.tldr: The paper introduces 'DoublyAware,' an uncertainty-aware extension to TD-MPC, which explicitly handles uncertainties in robot locomotion learning through structured modeling and adaptive constraints. This approach leads to improved learning efficiency and feasibility in humanoid robot movements.
