end of standard transceivers. By encoding weights and activations onto RF
carriers and using native mixers as computation units, MIWEN eliminates local
weight memory and the overhead of analog-to-digital and digital-to-analog
conversion. We derive the effective number of bits of radio-frequency analog
computation under thermal noise, quantify the energy--precision trade-off, and
demonstrate digital-comparable MNIST accuracy at orders-of-magnitude lower
energy, unlocking real-time inference on low-power, memory-free edge devices.

AI.tldr: MIWEN introduces an RF analog architecture for DNN inference to eliminate local weight memory, achieving energy-efficient classification on low-power edge devices.
AI.motivation: To overcome the bottleneck of costly weight storage and data movement in DNN inference on power-constrained edge devices.
AI.method: The paper proposes a unique RF analog architecture, MIWEN, which wirelessly streams weights, encodes weights and activations onto RF carriers, and utilizes native mixers for computation without requiring local weight memory.
AI.result: The research shows digital-comparable MNIST accuracy while achieving significant energy reductions for real-time inference on low-power, memory-free edge devices.
AI.conclusion: MIWEN facilitates efficient DNN inference by leveraging RF analog computation, paving the way for energy-precision trade-offs and enabling advanced applications on constrained hardware.

title: Directed Acyclic Graph Convolutional Networks
summary:
Directed acyclic graphs (DAGs) are central to science and engineering
applications including causal inference, scheduling, and neural architecture
search. In this work, we introduce the DAG Convolutional Network (DCN), a novel
graph neural network (GNN) architecture designed specifically for convolutional
learning from signals supported on DAGs. The DCN leverages causal graph filters
to learn nodal representations that account for the partial ordering inherent
to DAGs, a strong inductive bias does not present in conventional GNNs. Unlike
prior art in machine learning over DAGs, DCN builds on formal convolutional
operations that admit spectral-domain representations. We further propose the
Parallel DCN (PDCN), a model that feeds input DAG signals to a parallel bank of
causal graph-shift operators and processes these DAG-aware features using a
shared multilayer perceptron. This way, PDCN decouples model complexity from
graph size while maintaining satisfactory predictive performance. The
architectures' permutation equivariance and expressive power properties are
also established. Comprehensive numerical tests across several tasks, datasets,
and experimental conditions demonstrate that (P)DCN compares favorably with
state-of-the-art baselines in terms of accuracy, robustness, and computational
efficiency. These results position (P)DCN as a viable framework for deep
learning from DAG-structured data that is designed from first (graph) signal
processing principles.

AI.tldr: The paper introduces DAG Convolutional Network (DCN) and Parallel DCN (PDCN), novel graph neural network architectures optimized for directed acyclic graphs, proving their superior performance in convolutional learning.
AI.motivation: To address the challenge of applying convolutional learning techniques specifically to signals supported on DAGs, leveraging their inherent partial ordering.
AI.method: Developed DCN using causal graph filters for nodal representation and PDCN with parallel causal graph operations plus a shared multilayer perceptron. Both designs ensure permutation equivariance and scalability.
AI.result: The architectures outperform existing approaches in accuracy, robustness, and efficiency across different datasets and tasks.
AI.conclusion: (P)DCN is presented as a promising, efficient deep learning framework for DAG-structured data, built upon graph signal processing principles.

title: ViT-NeBLa: A Hybrid Vision Transformer and Neural Beer-Lambert Framework for Single-View 3D Reconstruction of Oral Anatomy from Panoramic Radiographs
summary:
Dental diagnosis relies on two primary imaging modalities: panoramic
radiographs (PX) providing 2D oral cavity representations, and Cone-Beam
Computed Tomography (CBCT) offering detailed 3D anatomical information. While
PX images are cost-effective and accessible, their lack of depth information
limits diagnostic accuracy. CBCT addresses this but presents drawbacks
including higher costs, increased radiation exposure, and limited
accessibility. Existing reconstruction models further complicate the process by
requiring CBCT flattening or prior dental arch information, often unavailable
clinically. We introduce ViT-NeBLa, a vision transformer-based Neural
Beer-Lambert model enabling accurate 3D reconstruction directly from single PX.
Our key innovations include: (1) enhancing the NeBLa framework with Vision
Transformers for improved reconstruction capabilities without requiring CBCT
flattening or prior dental arch information, (2) implementing a novel
horseshoe-shaped point sampling strategy with non-intersecting rays that
eliminates intermediate density aggregation required by existing models due to
intersecting rays, reducing sampling point computations by $52 \%$, (3)
replacing CNN-based U-Net with a hybrid ViT-CNN architecture for superior
global and local feature extraction, and (4) implementing learnable hash
positional encoding for better higher-dimensional representation of 3D sample
points compared to existing Fourier-based dense positional encoding.
Experiments demonstrate that ViT-NeBLa significantly outperforms prior
state-of-the-art methods both quantitatively and qualitatively, offering a
cost-effective, radiation-efficient alternative for enhanced dental
diagnostics.

AI.tldr: ViT-NeBLa, a vision transformer-based model, enables direct 3D dental reconstruction from single 2D panoramic radiographs, outperforming existing methods both quantitatively and qualitatively.
AI.motivation: The motivation is to address the limitations of panoramic radiographs (lacking depth information) and Cone-Beam Computed Tomography (costly, higher radiation, limited access) in dental diagnosis.
AI.method: The paper introduces ViT-NeBLa, a vision transformer-based Neural Beer-Lambert model, incorporating innovations like a hybrid ViT-CNN architecture, novel point sampling strategy, and learnable hash positional encoding.
AI.result: ViT-NeBLa achieves better performance than state-of-the-art methods in 3D reconstruction while offering reduced computation and improved diagnostic efficiency.
AI.conclusion: ViT-NeBLa provides a cost-effective and radiation-efficient solution for enhanced dental diagnostics, eliminating the need for CBCT flattening or dental arch priors.

title: MEraser: An Effective Fingerprint Erasure Approach for Large Language Models
comment: Accepted by ACL 2025, Main Conference, Long Paper
summary:
Large Language Models (LLMs) have become increasingly prevalent across
various sectors, raising critical concerns about model ownership and
intellectual property protection. Although backdoor-based fingerprinting has
emerged as a promising solution for model authentication, effective attacks for
removing these fingerprints remain largely unexplored. Therefore, we present
Mismatched Eraser (MEraser), a novel method for effectively removing
backdoor-based fingerprints from LLMs while maintaining model performance. Our
approach leverages a two-phase fine-tuning strategy utilizing carefully
constructed mismatched and clean datasets. Through extensive evaluation across
multiple LLM architectures and fingerprinting methods, we demonstrate that
MEraser achieves complete fingerprinting removal while maintaining model
performance with minimal training data of fewer than 1,000 samples.
Furthermore, we introduce a transferable erasure mechanism that enables
effective fingerprinting removal across different models without repeated
training. In conclusion, our approach provides a practical solution for
fingerprinting removal in LLMs, reveals critical vulnerabilities in current
fingerprinting techniques, and establishes comprehensive evaluation benchmarks
for developing more resilient model protection methods in the future.

AI.tldr: The paper introduces MEraser, a technique to remove backdoor-based fingerprints from large language models (LLMs) while preserving their performance.
AI.motivation: Current backdoor-based fingerprinting solutions for model authentication lack exploration of effective fingerprint removal techniques, which is crucial in ensuring intellectual property protection for LLMs.
AI.method: The authors propose a two-phase fine-tuning strategy using mismatched and clean datasets to remove fingerprints effectively. They also design a transferable erasure mechanism for cross-model fingerprint removal without repeated training.
AI.result: Experimental results show that MEraser successfully achieves complete fingerprinting removal while maintaining the original LLM's performance, using fewer than 1,000 training samples.
AI.conclusion: MEraser provides a practical solution for removing fingerprints from LLMs, exposes vulnerabilities in current fingerprinting techniques, and sets benchmarks for more robust model protection methods.

title: Brain Imaging Foundation Models, Are We There Yet? A Systematic Review of Foundation Models for Brain Imaging and Biomedical Research
summary:
Foundation models (FMs), large neural networks pretrained on extensive and
diverse datasets, have revolutionized artificial intelligence and shown
significant promise in medical imaging by enabling robust performance with
limited labeled data. Although numerous surveys have reviewed the application
of FM in healthcare care, brain imaging remains underrepresented, despite its
critical role in the diagnosis and treatment of neurological diseases using
modalities such as MRI, CT, and PET. Existing reviews either marginalize brain
imaging or lack depth on the unique challenges and requirements of FM in this
domain, such as multimodal data integration, support for diverse clinical
tasks, and handling of heterogeneous, fragmented datasets.
  To address this gap, we present the first comprehensive and curated review of
FMs for brain imaging. We systematically analyze 161 brain imaging datasets and
86 FM architectures, providing information on key design choices, training
paradigms, and optimizations driving recent advances. Our review highlights the
leading models for various brain imaging tasks, summarizes their innovations,
and critically examines current limitations and blind spots in the literature.
We conclude by outlining future research directions to advance FM applications
in brain imaging, with the aim of fostering progress in both clinical and
research settings.

AI.tldr: Foundation models (FMs), large neural networks pretrained on diverse datasets, have shown potential in medical imaging but are underexplored in brain imaging. This paper reviews challenges, architectures, and applications of FM in this domain.
AI.motivation: There is a gap in the existing literature regarding the in-depth application of foundation models in brain imaging, which is critical for neurological disease diagnosis and treatment.
AI.method: The authors analyze 161 brain imaging datasets and 86 FM architectures to explore design choices, training paradigms, and optimizations in the field.
AI.result: The paper identifies leading foundation models for brain imaging tasks, highlights their innovations, and discusses limitations and research blind spots.
AI.conclusion: Future research should focus on overcoming current limitations to enhance the applicability of foundation models in clinical and research settings for brain imaging.

title: TextureSplat: Per-Primitive Texture Mapping for Reflective Gaussian Splatting
comment: Code will be available at https://github.com/maeyounes/TextureSplat
summary:
Gaussian Splatting have demonstrated remarkable novel view synthesis
performance at high rendering frame rates. Optimization-based inverse rendering
within complex capture scenarios remains however a challenging problem. A
particular case is modelling complex surface light interactions for highly
reflective scenes, which results in intricate high frequency specular radiance
components. We hypothesize that such challenging settings can benefit from
increased representation power. We hence propose a method that tackles this
issue through a geometrically and physically grounded Gaussian Splatting borne
radiance field, where normals and material properties are spatially variable in
the primitive's local space. Using per-primitive texture maps for this purpose,
we also propose to harness the GPU hardware to accelerate rendering at test
time via unified material texture atlas.

AI.tldr: The paper proposes enhancing Gaussian Splatting for rendering complex scenes involving reflective materials by introducing spatially variable normals and materials in local space.
AI.motivation: Gaussian Splatting struggles with intricate light interactions in highly reflective and complex scenes, necessitating improved representation capabilities.
AI.method: The method introduces a geometrically and physically grounded Gaussian Splatting radiance field that uses per-primitive texture maps and a unified material texture atlas for efficient rendering.
AI.result: The approach provides enhanced representation power and GPU-accelerated rendering, effectively handling complex surface light interactions.
AI.conclusion: The proposed model achieves improved novel view synthesis in challenging scenarios with high-frequency specular components, overcoming the limitations of standard Gaussian Splatting.

title: Simple is what you need for efficient and accurate medical image segmentation
summary:
While modern segmentation models often prioritize performance over
practicality, we advocate a design philosophy prioritizing simplicity and
efficiency, and attempted high performance segmentation model design. This
paper presents SimpleUNet, a scalable ultra-lightweight medical image
segmentation model with three key innovations: (1) A partial feature selection
mechanism in skip connections for redundancy reduction while enhancing
segmentation performance; (2) A fixed-width architecture that prevents
exponential parameter growth across network stages; (3) An adaptive feature
fusion module achieving enhanced representation with minimal computational
overhead. With a record-breaking 16 KB parameter configuration, SimpleUNet
outperforms LBUNet and other lightweight benchmarks across multiple public
datasets. The 0.67 MB variant achieves superior efficiency (8.60 GFLOPs) and
accuracy, attaining a mean DSC/IoU of 85.76%/75.60% on multi-center breast
lesion datasets, surpassing both U-Net and TransUNet. Evaluations on skin
lesion datasets (ISIC 2017/2018: mDice 84.86%/88.77%) and endoscopic polyp
segmentation (KVASIR-SEG: 86.46%/76.48% mDice/mIoU) confirm consistent
dominance over state-of-the-art models. This work demonstrates that extreme
model compression need not compromise performance, providing new insights for
efficient and accurate medical image segmentation. Codes can be found at
https://github.com/Frankyu5666666/SimpleUNet.

AI.tldr: The paper introduces SimpleUNet, an efficient, ultra-lightweight model for medical image segmentation that achieves state-of-the-art performance with minimal computational resources.
AI.motivation: Modern segmentation models prioritize high performance but often overlook simplicity and efficiency. This paper seeks to address this gap by proposing a model with extreme scalability and practicality without sacrificing performance.
AI.method: SimpleUNet is designed with three innovations: (1) partial feature selection in skip connections for redundancy reduction, (2) a fixed-width architecture to prevent exponential parameter growth, and (3) an adaptive feature fusion module for better representation with minimal computation.
AI.result: With a parameter size as small as 16 KB, SimpleUNet outperforms existing lightweight segmentation benchmarks on various datasets. The 0.67 MB version achieves high efficiency (8.60 GFLOPs) and top-tier accuracy on multi-center breast lesion, skin lesion, and endoscopic polyp segmentation datasets, surpassing models like U-Net and TransUNet.
AI.conclusion: SimpleUNet proves that extreme model compression can coexist with high segmentation performance. It sets a new benchmark for efficient and accurate designs in medical image segmentation.

title: Audio-Visual Driven Compression for Low-Bitrate Talking Head Videos
summary:
Talking head video compression has advanced with neural rendering and
keypoint-based methods, but challenges remain, especially at low bit rates,
including handling large head movements, suboptimal lip synchronization, and
distorted facial reconstructions. To address these problems, we propose a novel
audio-visual driven video codec that integrates compact 3D motion features and
audio signals. This approach robustly models significant head rotations and
aligns lip movements with speech, improving both compression efficiency and
reconstruction quality. Experiments on the CelebV-HQ dataset show that our
method reduces bitrate by 22% compared to VVC and by 8.5% over state-of-the-art
learning-based codec. Furthermore, it provides superior lip-sync accuracy and
visual fidelity at comparable bitrates, highlighting its effectiveness in
bandwidth-constrained scenarios.

AI.tldr: The study introduces an audio-visual driven video codec that improves talking head video compression by reducing bitrates while enhancing lip-sync accuracy and visual quality, particularly for significant head movements.
AI.motivation: The motivation is to address the challenges of handling large head movements, subpar lip synchronization, and distorted facial reconstructions, especially at low bitrates in talking head video compression.
AI.method: The paper proposes an innovative codec integrating compact 3D motion features and audio signals to robustly model head rotations and align lip movements with speech, improving both compression and reconstruction quality.
AI.result: Experiments on the CelebV-HQ dataset demonstrate a 22% reduction in bitrate compared to VVC and 8.5% over state-of-the-art codecs, along with improved lip-sync accuracy and visual fidelity at comparable bitrates.
AI.conclusion: The proposed codec proves effective in bandwidth-constrained environments, offering significant advancements in compression efficiency and visual quality for talking head videos.

title: PRO: Projection Domain Synthesis for CT Imaging
summary:
Synthesizing high quality CT images remains a signifi-cant challenge due to
the limited availability of annotat-ed data and the complex nature of CT
imaging. In this work, we present PRO, a novel framework that, to the best of
our knowledge, is the first to perform CT image synthesis in the projection
domain using latent diffusion models. Unlike previous approaches that operate
in the image domain, PRO learns rich structural representa-tions from raw
projection data and leverages anatomi-cal text prompts for controllable
synthesis. This projec-tion domain strategy enables more faithful modeling of
underlying imaging physics and anatomical structures. Moreover, PRO functions
as a foundation model, capa-ble of generalizing across diverse downstream tasks
by adjusting its generative behavior via prompt inputs. Experimental results
demonstrated that incorporating our synthesized data significantly improves
perfor-mance across multiple downstream tasks, including low-dose and
sparse-view reconstruction, even with limited training data. These findings
underscore the versatility and scalability of PRO in data generation for
various CT applications. These results highlight the potential of projection
domain synthesis as a powerful tool for data augmentation and robust CT
imaging. Our source code is publicly available at:
https://github.com/yqx7150/PRO.

AI.tldr: PRO framework uses latent diffusion models for projection domain CT image synthesis, improving performance across tasks.
AI.motivation: There is limited annotated data and complex imaging challenges in CT synthesis, necessitating innovative approaches.
AI.method: Develops PRO framework using latent diffusion models in the projection domain with anatomical text prompts for CT image synthesis.
AI.result: Enhanced downstream task performance, including low-dose and sparse-view reconstruction using generated data.
AI.conclusion: Projection domain synthesis via PRO demonstrates scalability and versatility, offering robust data augmentation for CT imaging.

title: SplashNet: Split-and-Share Encoders for Accurate and Efficient Typing with Surface Electromyography
summary:
Surface electromyography (sEMG) at the wrists could enable natural,
keyboard-free text entry, yet the state-of-the-art emg2qwerty baseline still
misrecognizes $51.8\%$ of characters in the zero-shot setting on unseen users
and $7.0\%$ after user-specific fine-tuning. We trace many of these errors to
mismatched cross-user signal statistics, fragile reliance on high-order feature
dependencies, and the absence of architectural inductive biases aligned with
the bilateral nature of typing. To address these issues, we introduce three
simple modifications: (i) Rolling Time Normalization, which adaptively aligns
input distributions across users; (ii) Aggressive Channel Masking, which
encourages reliance on low-order feature combinations more likely to generalize
across users; and (iii) a Split-and-Share encoder that processes each hand
independently with weight-shared streams to reflect the bilateral symmetry of
the neuromuscular system. Combined with a five-fold reduction in spectral
resolution ($33\!\rightarrow\!6$ frequency bands), these components yield a
compact Split-and-Share model, SplashNet-mini, which uses only $\tfrac14$ the
parameters and $0.6\times$ the FLOPs of the baseline while reducing
character-error rate (CER) to $36.4\%$ zero-shot and $5.9\%$ after fine-tuning.
An upscaled variant, SplashNet ($\tfrac12$ the parameters, $1.15\times$ the
FLOPs of the baseline), further lowers error to $35.7\%$ and $5.5\%$,
representing relative improvements of $31\%$ and $21\%$ in the zero-shot and
fine-tuned settings, respectively. SplashNet therefore establishes a new state
of the art without requiring additional data.

AI.tldr: The paper introduces SplashNet, an improved model for sEMG-based text input, which significantly reduces character error rates both in zero-shot and fine-tuned settings.
AI.motivation: The high error rates in existing sEMG-based text input systems are due to mismatched cross-user signal statistics, over-reliance on high-order feature dependencies, and lack of neural architecture alignment with the bilateral nature of typing.
AI.method: The authors propose three modifications: Rolling Time Normalization for cross-user alignment, Aggressive Channel Masking to generalize features across users, and a Split-and-Share encoder to align with neuromuscular bilateral symmetry. They also reduce spectral resolution and optimize model parameters to create SplashNet.
AI.result: The compact SplashNet-mini achieves a 36.4% character error rate (CER) zero-shot and 5.9% fine-tuned, while the upscaled SplashNet further reduces these rates to 35.7% and 5.5%, outperforming state-of-the-art baselines.
AI.conclusion: SplashNet effectively improves generalization and efficiency in sEMG-based text input systems, establishing a new state-of-the-art without additional data requirements.

title: From Flat to Feeling: A Feasibility and Impact Study on Dynamic Facial Emotions in AI-Generated Avatars
summary:
Dynamic facial emotion is essential for believable AI-generated avatars;
however, most systems remain visually inert, limiting their utility in
high-stakes simulations such as virtual training for investigative interviews
with abused children. We introduce and evaluate a real-time architecture fusing
Unreal Engine 5 MetaHuman rendering with NVIDIA Omniverse Audio2Face to
translate vocal prosody into high-fidelity facial expressions on photorealistic
child avatars. We implemented a distributed two-PC setup that decouples
language processing and speech synthesis from GPU-intensive rendering, designed
to support low-latency interaction in desktop and VR environments. A
between-subjects study ($N=70$) using audio+visual and visual-only conditions
assessed perceptual impacts as participants rated emotional clarity, facial
realism, and empathy for two avatars expressing joy, sadness, and anger.
  Results demonstrate that avatars could express emotions recognizably, with
sadness and joy achieving high identification rates. However, anger recognition
significantly dropped without audio, highlighting the importance of congruent
vocal cues for high-arousal emotions. Interestingly, removing audio boosted
perceived facial realism, suggesting that audiovisual desynchrony remains a key
design challenge. These findings confirm the technical feasibility of
generating emotionally expressive avatars and provide guidance for improving
non-verbal communication in sensitive training simulations.

AI.tldr: The paper presents a system integrating Unreal Engine 5 MetaHuman with NVIDIA Omniverse Audio2Face for real-time emotion-driven facial expressions on child avatars, aimed at virtual training settings like investigative interviews.
AI.motivation: To address current limitations in generating dynamic facial emotions for AI avatars, especially for high-stakes scenarios like virtual training in investigative interviews with children.
AI.method: The approach combines Unreal Engine 5 MetaHuman rendering with NVIDIA Omniverse Audio2Face in a distributed two-PC setup to translate vocal prosody into lifelike facial expressions, supporting low-latency interaction. A study evaluated emotional clarity and user perception of two avatars under audio+visual and visual-only conditions.
AI.result: The system allowed recognizable expression of sadness and joy but struggled with anger in the visual-only condition, demonstrating the role of vocal cues. Removing audio improved perceived facial realism, though audiovisual desynchrony remains a challenge.
AI.conclusion: The architecture proves technically feasible for creating emotionally expressive avatars and provides actionable insights to enhance non-verbal communication in sensitive applications like virtual training.

title: MultiViT2: A Data-augmented Multimodal Neuroimaging Prediction Framework via Latent Diffusion Model
summary:
Multimodal medical imaging integrates diverse data types, such as structural
and functional neuroimaging, to provide complementary insights that enhance
deep learning predictions and improve outcomes. This study focuses on a
neuroimaging prediction framework based on both structural and functional
neuroimaging data. We propose a next-generation prediction model,
\textbf{MultiViT2}, which combines a pretrained representative learning base
model with a vision transformer backbone for prediction output. Additionally,
we developed a data augmentation module based on the latent diffusion model
that enriches input data by generating augmented neuroimaging samples, thereby
enhancing predictive performance through reduced overfitting and improved
generalizability. We show that MultiViT2 significantly outperforms the
first-generation model in schizophrenia classification accuracy and
demonstrates strong scalability and portability.

AI.tldr: The study introduces MultiViT2, a model combining vision transformers with augmented multimodal neuroimaging data for improved schizophrenia classification.
AI.motivation: To enhance predictive accuracy and generalizability in medical neuroimaging using deep learning models that combine structural and functional data.
AI.method: They propose MultiViT2, which merges pretrained representation learning, vision transformers, and latent diffusion-based data augmentation to improve predictions.
AI.result: MultiViT2 achieved superior results compared to its predecessor model, particularly in schizophrenia classification accuracy, with improved scalability and portability.
AI.conclusion: MultiViT2 effectively leverages multimodal imaging and advanced augmentation to set a new benchmark in neuroimaging predictions.

title: ANIRA: An Architecture for Neural Network Inference in Real-Time Audio Applications
comment:
8 pages, accepted to the Proceedings of the 5th IEEE International
  Symposium on the Internet of Sounds (2024) - repository:
  github.com/anira-project/anira
summary:
Numerous tools for neural network inference are currently available, yet many
do not meet the requirements of real-time audio applications. In response, we
introduce anira, an efficient cross-platform library. To ensure compatibility
with a broad range of neural network architectures and frameworks, anira
supports ONNX Runtime, LibTorch, and TensorFlow Lite as backends. Each
inference engine exhibits real-time violations, which anira mitigates by
decoupling the inference from the audio callback to a static thread pool. The
library incorporates built-in latency management and extensive benchmarking
capabilities, both crucial to ensure a continuous signal flow. Three different
neural network architectures for audio effect emulation are then subjected to
benchmarking across various configurations. Statistical modeling is employed to
identify the influence of various factors on performance. The findings indicate
that for stateless models, ONNX Runtime exhibits the lowest runtimes. For
stateful models, LibTorch demonstrates the fastest performance. Our results
also indicate that for certain model-engine combinations, the initial
inferences take longer, particularly when these inferences exhibit a higher
incidence of real-time violations.

AI.tldr: The paper introduces Anira, a cross-platform library for efficient real-time audio application inference, benchmarking various neural network architectures for performance.
AI.motivation: Real-time audio applications require neural network inference tools, many of which fail to meet performance requirements.
AI.method: Anira mitigates real-time violations by decoupling inference operations using thread pools, employing latency management, and benchmark testing multiple architectures.
AI.result: ONNX Runtime performs best for stateless models, while LibTorch leads for stateful ones, with initial inferences showing higher latency and real-time violations in some cases.
AI.conclusion: Anira enhances compatibility and performance across different neural network engines, ensuring continuous signal flow for real-time audio applications.

title: Alphabet Index Mapping: Jailbreaking LLMs through Semantic Dissimilarity
summary:
Large Language Models (LLMs) have demonstrated remarkable capabilities, yet
their susceptibility to adversarial attacks, particularly jailbreaking, poses
significant safety and ethical concerns. While numerous jailbreak methods
exist, many suffer from computational expense, high token usage, or complex
decoding schemes. Liu et al. (2024) introduced FlipAttack, a black-box method
that achieves high attack success rates (ASR) through simple prompt
manipulation. This paper investigates the underlying mechanisms of FlipAttack's
effectiveness by analyzing the semantic changes induced by its flipping modes.
We hypothesize that semantic dissimilarity between original and manipulated
prompts is inversely correlated with ASR. To test this, we examine embedding
space visualizations (UMAP, KDE) and cosine similarities for FlipAttack's
modes. Furthermore, we introduce a novel adversarial attack, Alphabet Index
Mapping (AIM), designed to maximize semantic dissimilarity while maintaining
simple decodability. Experiments on GPT-4 using a subset of AdvBench show AIM
and its variant AIM+FWO achieve a 94% ASR, outperforming FlipAttack and other
methods on this subset. Our findings suggest that while high semantic
dissimilarity is crucial, a balance with decoding simplicity is key for
successful jailbreaking. This work contributes to a deeper understanding of
adversarial prompt mechanics and offers a new, effective jailbreak technique.

AI.tldr: The paper evaluates the vulnerabilities of large language models (LLMs) to adversarial attacks, focusing on analyzing FlipAttack and proposing a new attack method, AIM, which achieves higher success rates.
AI.motivation: The paper highlights concerns about the safety and ethical risks caused by adversarial attacks, especially jailbreaking methods on LLMs, and aims to understand and improve upon existing techniques like FlipAttack.
AI.method: The authors analyze the semantic shifts induced by FlipAttack's flipping modes, use embedding space visualizations (UMAP, KDE) and cosine similarity, and propose a new attack method called Alphabet Index Mapping (AIM) to optimize semantic dissimilarity and decoding simplicity.
AI.result: The proposed AIM method, along with its variant AIM+FWO, achieves a 94% attack success rate on a subset of AdvBench, outperforming FlipAttack and other jailbreak techniques.
AI.conclusion: Maintaining a balance between semantic dissimilarity and decoding simplicity is vital for successful adversarial attacks, and the study provides insights into adversarial prompt mechanics while introducing a highly effective attack technique.

title: Noise tolerance via reinforcement: Learning a reinforced quantum dynamics
summary:
The performance of quantum simulations heavily depends on the efficiency of
noise mitigation techniques and error correction algorithms. Reinforcement has
emerged as a powerful strategy to enhance the performance of learning and
optimization algorithms. In this study, we demonstrate that reinforced quantum
dynamics can exhibit significant robustness against interactions with a noisy
environment. We study a quantum annealing process where, through reinforcement,
the system is encouraged to maintain its current state or follow a noise-free
evolution. A learning algorithm is employed to find a concise approximation of
this reinforced dynamics, reducing the total evolution time and, consequently,
the system's exposure to noisy interactions. This approach also avoids the
complexities associated with implementing quantum feedback in such algorithms.
The efficacy of our method is demonstrated through numerical simulations of
reinforced quantum annealing with one- and two-qubit systems under Pauli noise.

AI.tldr: The study proposes using reinforcement to improve quantum annealing processes, showing resilience against noisy environments via simulations.
AI.motivation: To enhance the efficiency of quantum simulation by improving robustness against noise using reinforcement methods.
AI.method: The method involves applying reinforcement in quantum annealing to encourage noise-free evolution and using a learning algorithm to optimize dynamics, tested with numerical simulations under Pauli noise.
AI.result: Numerical simulations show that reinforced quantum annealing improves robustness and reduces exposure to noisy interactions for one- and two-qubit systems.
AI.conclusion: Reinforced quantum annealing is a promising method for mitigating noise in quantum systems, offering improvements without adding the complexity of quantum feedback.

title: UltraZoom: Generating Gigapixel Images from Regular Photos
summary:
We present UltraZoom, a system for generating gigapixel-resolution images of
objects from casually captured inputs, such as handheld phone photos. Given a
full-shot image (global, low-detail) and one or more close-ups (local,
high-detail), UltraZoom upscales the full image to match the fine detail and
scale of the close-up examples. To achieve this, we construct a per-instance
paired dataset from the close-ups and adapt a pretrained generative model to
learn object-specific low-to-high resolution mappings. At inference, we apply
the model in a sliding window fashion over the full image. Constructing these
pairs is non-trivial: it requires registering the close-ups within the full
image for scale estimation and degradation alignment. We introduce a simple,
robust method for getting registration on arbitrary materials in casual,
in-the-wild captures. Together, these components form a system that enables
seamless pan and zoom across the entire object, producing consistent,
photorealistic gigapixel imagery from minimal input.

AI.tldr: UltraZoom creates gigapixel images from casual smartphone photos by upscaling low-detail full shots to match the fine details in close-ups.
AI.motivation: To enable photorealistic gigapixel-resolution imagery from everyday casual images with minimal input.
AI.method: UltraZoom constructs paired datasets from close-ups and adapts pre-trained generative models using a simple registration method for seamless upscaling.
AI.result: The system successfully achieves consistent, photorealistic gigapixel resolution imagery from handheld phone photos.
AI.conclusion: UltraZoom offers a practical method to produce ultra-high-resolution images, enhancing zoom and pan functionalities across objects with minimal inputs.

title: Adjusted Shuffling SARAH: Advancing Complexity Analysis via Dynamic Gradient Weighting
summary:
In this paper, we propose Adjusted Shuffling SARAH, a novel algorithm that
integrates shuffling techniques with the well-known variance-reduced algorithm
SARAH while dynamically adjusting the stochastic gradient weights in each
update to enhance exploration. Our method achieves the best-known gradient
complexity for shuffling variance reduction methods in a strongly convex
setting. This result applies to any shuffling technique, which narrows the gap
in the complexity analysis of variance reduction methods between uniform
sampling and shuffling data. Furthermore, we introduce Inexact Adjusted
Reshuffling SARAH, an inexact variant of Adjusted Shuffling SARAH that
eliminates the need for full-batch gradient computations. This algorithm
retains the same linear convergence rate as Adjusted Shuffling SARAH while
showing an advantage in total complexity when the sample size is very large.

AI.tldr: The paper introduces Adjusted Shuffling SARAH, a new algorithm that combines shuffling techniques with SARAH for improved gradient complexity in strongly convex settings. It also presents an inexact variant to reduce total complexity for large sample sizes.
AI.motivation: Address the gap in complexity between uniform sampling and shuffling data in variance reduction methods, while improving exploration and efficiency.
AI.method: The Adjusted Shuffling SARAH algorithm integrates shuffling techniques with SARAH, dynamically adjusting stochastic gradient weights. The inexact variant eliminates full-batch computations while maintaining linear convergence.
AI.result: Adjusted Shuffling SARAH achieves the best-known gradient complexity for shuffling variance reduction methods in strongly convex settings. The inexact variant proves advantageous for very large sample sizes.
AI.conclusion: The proposed methods improve the efficiency of variance reduction approaches with shuffling, enhancing practical applications, especially for large datasets.

title: Learning Best Paths in Quantum Networks
summary:
Quantum networks (QNs) transmit delicate quantum information across noisy
quantum channels. Crucial applications, like quantum key distribution (QKD) and
distributed quantum computation (DQC), rely on efficient quantum information
transmission. Learning the best path between a pair of end nodes in a QN is key
to enhancing such applications. This paper addresses learning the best path in
a QN in the online learning setting. We explore two types of feedback:
"link-level" and "path-level". Link-level feedback pertains to QNs with
advanced quantum switches that enable link-level benchmarking. Path-level
feedback, on the other hand, is associated with basic quantum switches that
permit only path-level benchmarking. We introduce two online learning
algorithms, BeQuP-Link and BeQuP-Path, to identify the best path using
link-level and path-level feedback, respectively. To learn the best path,
BeQuP-Link benchmarks the critical links dynamically, while BeQuP-Path relies
on a subroutine, transferring path-level observations to estimate link-level
parameters in a batch manner. We analyze the quantum resource complexity of
these algorithms and demonstrate that both can efficiently and, with high
probability, determine the best path. Finally, we perform NetSquid-based
simulations and validate that both algorithms accurately and efficiently
identify the best path.

AI.tldr: The paper addresses finding the best path in quantum networks through two online learning algorithms, BeQuP-Link and BeQuP-Path, focusing on two levels of feedback: link-level and path-level.
AI.motivation: Quantum networks suffer from noisy quantum channels, and determining efficient quantum information transmission paths is essential for applications like quantum key distribution and distributed quantum computation.
AI.method: The authors propose two online learning algorithms: BeQuP-Link, which uses dynamic link-level benchmarking, and BeQuP-Path, which transforms path-level observations into link-level parameter estimates in batch.
AI.result: Both algorithms effectively identify the best path in a quantum network with high probability and efficient resource complexity, as validated through NetSquid-based simulations.
AI.conclusion: The study presents novel algorithms that allow efficient path selection in quantum networks, enabling enhanced applications in quantum communication.

title: Symmetry-preserving neural networks in lattice field theories
summary:
This thesis deals with neural networks that respect symmetries and presents
the advantages in applying them to lattice field theory problems. The concept
of equivariance is explained, together with the reason why such a property is
crucial for the network to preserve the desired symmetry. The benefits of
choosing equivariant networks are first illustrated for translational symmetry
on a complex scalar field toy model. The discussion is then extended to gauge
theories, for which Lattice Gauge Equivariant Convolutional Neural Networks
(L-CNNs) are specifically designed ad hoc. Regressions of physical observables
such as Wilson loops are successfully solved by L-CNNs, whereas traditional
architectures which are not gauge symmetric perform significantly worse.
Finally, we introduce the technique of neural gradient flow, which is an
ordinary differential equation solved by neural networks, and propose it as a
method to generate lattice gauge configurations.

AI.tldr: The paper explores neural networks respecting symmetries and their advantages in lattice field theory, focusing on equivariant networks and their applications to translational and gauge symmetries.
AI.motivation: To address the problem of preserving desired symmetries in neural network applications to lattice field theory.
AI.method: The paper develops equivariant neural networks tailored for translational and gauge symmetries, such as Lattice Gauge Equivariant Convolutional Neural Networks (L-CNNs), and also introduces neural gradient flow for lattice gauge configuration generation.
AI.result: L-CNNs outperformed traditional architectures in predicting physical observables like Wilson loops, and neural gradient flow was proposed as an effective technique for lattice gauge configuration.
AI.conclusion: Equivariant neural networks provide significant benefits in symmetry-preserving applications, highlighting their usefulness for problems in lattice field theory and beyond.

title: Information fusion strategy integrating pre-trained language model and contrastive learning for materials knowledge mining
summary:
Machine learning has revolutionized materials design, yet predicting complex
properties like alloy ductility remains challenging due to the influence of
processing conditions and microstructural features that resist quantification
through traditional reductionist approaches. Here, we present an innovative
information fusion architecture that integrates domain-specific texts from
materials science literature with quantitative physical descriptors to overcome
these limitations. Our framework employs MatSciBERT for advanced textual
comprehension and incorporates contrastive learning to automatically extract
implicit knowledge regarding processing parameters and microstructural
characteristics. Through rigorous ablation studies and comparative experiments,
the model demonstrates superior performance, achieving coefficient of
determination (R2) values of 0.849 and 0.680 on titanium alloy validation set
and refractory multi-principal-element alloy test set. This systematic approach
provides a holistic framework for property prediction in complex material
systems where quantitative descriptors are incomplete and establishes a
foundation for knowledge-guided materials design and informatics-driven
materials discovery.

AI.tldr: This paper introduces a new architecture combining textual data and physical descriptors to predict complex materials properties like ductility.
AI.motivation: Forecasting alloy ductility is difficult due to processing conditions and features that traditional methods struggle to quantify.
AI.method: The study uses MatSciBERT and contrastive learning to merge textual information with quantitative physical data.
AI.result: Achieved high R2 values of 0.849 (titanium alloy validation set) and 0.680 (refractory alloy test set).
AI.conclusion: The framework facilitates holistic property prediction in complex materials systems and aims to enable informatics-driven materials discovery.

title: Solving tricky quantum optics problems with assistance from (artificial) intelligence
summary:
The capabilities of modern artificial intelligence (AI) as a ``scientific
collaborator'' are explored by engaging it with three nuanced problems in
quantum optics: state populations in optical pumping, resonant transitions
between decaying states (the Burshtein effect), and degenerate mirrorless
lasing. Through iterative dialogue, the authors observe that AI models--when
prompted and corrected--can reason through complex scenarios, refine their
answers, and provide expert-level guidance, closely resembling the interaction
with an adept colleague. The findings highlight that AI democratizes access to
sophisticated modeling and analysis, shifting the focus in scientific practice
from technical mastery to the generation and testing of ideas, and reducing the
time for completing research tasks from days to minutes.

AI.tldr: The study examines modern AI's role as a collaborator in quantum optics research, showcasing its capacity for iterative problem-solving and expert guidance.
AI.motivation: To investigate AI's potential as a supportive scientific collaborator capable of complex reasoning and idea development in quantum optics.
AI.method: Engaging AI in iterative dialogue on three quantum optics scenarios (optical pumping, Burshtein effect, and degenerate mirrorless lasing) to assess its reasoning and problem-solving abilities.
AI.result: AI demonstrated expert-level reasoning, refining its responses through iteration, and significantly reduced the time required for research tasks.
AI.conclusion: AI can act as an adept scientific partner, democratizing access to complex analyses and reshaping scientific workflows toward idea generation rather than technical execution.

title: Glocal Smoothness: Line Search can really help!
summary:
Iteration complexities for first-order optimization algorithms are typically
stated in terms of a global Lipschitz constant of the gradient, and
near-optimal results are achieved using fixed step sizes. But many objective
functions that arise in practice have regions with small Lipschitz constants
where larger step sizes can be used. Many local Lipschitz assumptions have been
proposed, which have lead to results showing that adaptive step sizes and/or
line searches yield improved convergence rates over fixed step sizes. However,
these faster rates tend to depend on the iterates of the algorithm, which makes
it difficult to compare the iteration complexities of different methods. We
consider a simple characterization of global and local ("glocal") smoothness
that only depends on properties of the function. This allows upper bounds on
iteration complexities in terms of iterate-independent constants and enables us
to compare iteration complexities between algorithms. Under this assumption it
is straightforward to show the advantages of line searches over fixed step
sizes, and that in some settings, gradient descent with line search has a
better iteration complexity than accelerated methods with fixed step sizes. We
further show that glocal smoothness can lead to improved complexities for the
Polyak and AdGD step sizes, as well other algorithms including coordinate
optimization, stochastic gradient methods, accelerated gradient methods, and
non-linear conjugate gradient methods.

AI.tldr: This paper proposes a novel 'glocal' smoothness characterization to improve iteration complexity analysis in optimization algorithms, enabling direct comparison of fixed and adaptive step-size methods.
AI.motivation: To enhance optimization algorithm efficiency by utilizing local smoothness properties of objective functions, which are often overlooked by traditional global gradient-based assumptions.
AI.method: Introduce 'glocal' smoothness bounds that incorporate both global and local properties to predict iteration complexities independent of algorithm iterates.
AI.result: The new framework demonstrates the benefits of adaptive methods like line searches and highlights improved performance of step-size strategies over fixed methods across various optimization approaches.
AI.conclusion: 'Glocal' smoothness provides a unified basis for analyzing iteration complexities, revealing gains for several optimization algorithms over fixed step-size methods.

title: Resilient-native and Intelligent NextG Systems
summary:
Just like power, water and transportation systems, wireless networks are a
crucial societal infrastructure. As natural and human-induced disruptions
continue to grow, wireless networks must be resilient to unforeseen events,
able to withstand and recover from unexpected adverse conditions, shocks,
unmodeled disturbances and cascading failures. Despite its critical importance,
resilience remains an elusive concept, with its mathematical foundations still
underdeveloped. Unlike robustness and reliability, resilience is premised on
the fact that disruptions will inevitably happen. Resilience, in terms of
elasticity, focuses on the ability to bounce back to favorable states, while
resilience as plasticity involves agents (or networks) that can flexibly expand
their states, hypotheses and course of actions, by transforming through
real-time adaptation and reconfiguration. This constant situational awareness
and vigilance of adapting world models and counterfactually reasoning about
potential system failures and the corresponding best responses, is a core
aspect of resilience. This article seeks to first define resilience and
disambiguate it from reliability and robustness, before delving into the
mathematics of resilience. Finally, the article concludes by presenting nuanced
metrics and discussing trade-offs tailored to the unique characteristics of
network resilience.

AI.tldr: This paper addresses resilience in wireless networks, detailing its definition, distinctions from reliability and robustness, and proposes mathematical foundations along with tailored metrics and trade-offs for resilience.
AI.motivation: The motivation lies in the increasing importance of wireless networks as societal infrastructure and the necessity for these systems to be resilient to both natural and human-induced disruptions.
AI.method: The authors first define and differentiate resilience from reliability and robustness, followed by an exploration of the mathematical foundations of resilience and the proposal of nuanced metrics.
AI.result: The paper delivers a clear definition of resilience, delineates its complex nature, and proposes metrics and trade-offs tailored to the unique characteristics of network resilience.
AI.conclusion: Resilience is presented as a core requirement for wireless networks, emphasizing elasticity and plasticity to adapt and recover from disruptions, supported by quantitative metrics and strategic trade-offs.

title: INTERPOS: Interaction Rhythm Guided Positional Morphing for Mobile App Recommender Systems
summary:
The mobile app market has expanded exponentially, offering millions of apps
with diverse functionalities, yet research in mobile app recommendation remains
limited. Traditional sequential recommender systems utilize the order of items
in users' historical interactions to predict the next item for the users.
Position embeddings, well-established in transformer-based architectures for
natural language processing tasks, effectively distinguish token positions in
sequences. In sequential recommendation systems, position embeddings can
capture the order of items in a user's historical interaction sequence.
Nevertheless, this ordering does not consider the time elapsed between two
interactions of the same user (e.g., 1 day, 1 week, 1 month), referred to as
"user rhythm". In mobile app recommendation datasets, the time between
consecutive user interactions is notably longer compared to other domains like
movies, posing significant challenges for sequential recommender systems. To
address this phenomenon in the mobile app domain, we introduce INTERPOS, an
Interaction Rhythm Guided Positional Morphing strategy for autoregressive
mobile app recommender systems. INTERPOS incorporates rhythm-guided position
embeddings, providing a more comprehensive representation that considers both
the sequential order of interactions and the temporal gaps between them. This
approach enables a deep understanding of users' rhythms at a fine-grained
level, capturing the intricacies of their interaction patterns over time. We
propose three strategies to incorporate the morphed positional embeddings in
two transformer-based sequential recommendation system architectures. Our
extensive evaluations show that INTERPOS outperforms state-of-the-art models
using 7 mobile app recommendation datasets on NDCG@K and HIT@K metrics. The
source code of INTERPOS is available at https://github.com/dlgrad/INTERPOS.

AI.tldr: The paper introduces INTERPOS, a novel method enhancing mobile app recommendation by incorporating user interaction timing via rhythm-guided embeddings, to address limitations in sequential recommenders.
AI.motivation: The motivation behind this paper is to address the challenges in mobile app recommendation due to longer and varying time intervals between user interactions, which are not effectively captured by traditional positional embeddings in sequential recommendation systems.
AI.method: The proposed method, INTERPOS, introduces rhythm-guided positional embeddings that account for both sequential order of interactions and temporal gaps. It employs three strategies to incorporate these embeddings into two transformer-based recommender architectures.
AI.result: Extensive evaluations on seven mobile app recommendation datasets demonstrated that INTERPOS outperforms current state-of-the-art models on metrics like NDCG@K and HIT@K.
AI.conclusion: INTERPOS offers a novel approach to improving autoregressive mobile app recommendation by deeply capturing users' interaction rhythms. Its superior performance makes it a significant contribution to advancing recommendation systems.

title: Synesthesia of Machines (SoM)-Enhanced Sub-THz ISAC Transmission for Air-Ground Network
summary:
Integrated sensing and communication (ISAC) within sub-THz frequencies is
crucial for future air-ground networks, but unique propagation characteristics
and hardware limitations present challenges in optimizing ISAC performance
while increasing operational latency. This paper introduces a multi-modal
sensing fusion framework inspired by synesthesia of machine (SoM) to enhance
sub-THz ISAC transmission. By exploiting inherent degrees of freedom in sub-THz
hardware and channels, the framework optimizes the radio-frequency environment.
Squint-aware beam management is developed to improve air-ground network
adaptability, enabling three-dimensional dynamic ISAC links. Leveraging
multi-modal information, the framework enhances ISAC performance and reduces
latency. Visual data rapidly localizes users and targets, while a customized
multi-modal learning algorithm optimizes the hybrid precoder. A new metric
provides comprehensive performance evaluation, and extensive experiments
demonstrate that the proposed scheme significantly improves ISAC efficiency.

AI.tldr: The paper proposes a novel framework to improve integrated sensing and communication (ISAC) performance in sub-THz frequencies, addressing challenges caused by propagation characteristics and hardware limitations.
AI.motivation: The unique propagation characteristics and hardware limitations in sub-THz ISAC create challenges in optimizing performance and reducing latency in air-ground networks.
AI.method: A multi-modal sensing fusion framework, inspired by machine synesthesia, leverages sub-THz hardware and channel degrees of freedom, squint-aware beam management, visual data localization, and a learning-based hybrid precoder optimization to enhance ISAC efficiency.
AI.result: The framework significantly enhances ISAC performance, reduces operational latency, and provides dynamic adaptability in air-ground networks as demonstrated by extensive experiments.
AI.conclusion: The proposed fusion framework effectively addresses latency and performance optimization challenges, advancing sub-THz ISAC for future air-ground networks.

title: Privacy-Preserving Federated Learning against Malicious Clients Based on Verifiable Functional Encryption
summary:
Federated learning is a promising distributed learning paradigm that enables
collaborative model training without exposing local client data, thereby
protect data privacy. However, it also brings new threats and challenges. The
advancement of model inversion attacks has rendered the plaintext transmission
of local models insecure, while the distributed nature of federated learning
makes it particularly vulnerable to attacks raised by malicious clients. To
protect data privacy and prevent malicious client attacks, this paper proposes
a privacy-preserving federated learning framework based on verifiable
functional encryption, without a non-colluding dual-server setup or additional
trusted third-party. Specifically, we propose a novel decentralized verifiable
functional encryption (DVFE) scheme that enables the verification of specific
relationships over multi-dimensional ciphertexts. This scheme is formally
treated, in terms of definition, security model and security proof.
Furthermore, based on the proposed DVFE scheme, we design a privacy-preserving
federated learning framework VFEFL that incorporates a novel robust aggregation
rule to detect malicious clients, enabling the effective training of
high-accuracy models under adversarial settings. Finally, we provide formal
analysis and empirical evaluation of the proposed schemes. The results
demonstrate that our approach achieves the desired privacy protection,
robustness, verifiability and fidelity, while eliminating the reliance on
non-colluding dual-server settings or trusted third parties required by
existing methods.

AI.tldr: The paper proposes a privacy-preserving federated learning framework using decentralized verifiable functional encryption to address data privacy and malicious client issues.
AI.motivation: The paper aims to address the privacy and security challenges in federated learning, especially in protecting data privacy and countering malicious client attacks.
AI.method: The authors propose a decentralized verifiable functional encryption (DVFE) scheme, which enables verification over multi-dimensional ciphertexts, and integrate it into a federated learning framework (VFEFL) with a robust aggregation rule.
AI.result: The approach achieves privacy protection, robustness to adversarial attacks, verifiability, and model accuracy, without relying on a dual-server setup or third-party trust.
AI.conclusion: This study demonstrates a novel and effective methodology to enhance privacy and robustness in federated learning, improving its feasibility in adversarial and decentralized settings.

title: Exploring the Potential of Metacognitive Support Agents for Human-AI Co-Creation
comment:
26 pages, to be published in the proceedings of the Designing
  Interactive Systems Conference (DIS'25)
summary:
Despite the potential of generative AI (GenAI) design tools to enhance design
processes, professionals often struggle to integrate AI into their workflows.
Fundamental cognitive challenges include the need to specify all design
criteria as distinct parameters upfront (intent formulation) and designers'
reduced cognitive involvement in the design process due to cognitive
offloading, which can lead to insufficient problem exploration,
underspecification, and limited ability to evaluate outcomes. Motivated by
these challenges, we envision novel metacognitive support agents that assist
designers in working more reflectively with GenAI. To explore this vision, we
conducted exploratory prototyping through a Wizard of Oz elicitation study with
20 mechanical designers probing multiple metacognitive support strategies. We
found that agent-supported users created more feasible designs than
non-supported users, with differing impacts between support strategies. Based
on these findings, we discuss opportunities and tradeoffs of metacognitive
support agents and considerations for future AI-based design tools.

AI.tldr: The paper explores using metacognitive support agents to help designers work reflectively with generative AI tools, aiming to mitigate cognitive challenges.
AI.motivation: Professionals using generative AI tools face cognitive challenges like intent formulation and reduced engagement, leading to suboptimal problem exploration and design evaluation.
AI.method: The study uses a Wizard of Oz elicitation with 20 mechanical designers to test metacognitive support strategies.
AI.result: Agent-supported designers produced more feasible designs compared to those without support, with varying effects among different strategies.
AI.conclusion: Metacognitive support agents can enhance design outcomes and should be considered in future AI design tool development, with attention to their tradeoffs and impact.

title: eLog analysis for accelerators: status and future outlook
comment:
4 pages, 2 figures, 16th International Particle Accelerator
  Conference (IPAC'25)
summary:
This work demonstrates electronic logbook (eLog) systems leveraging modern
AI-driven information retrieval capabilities at the accelerator facilities of
Fermilab, Jefferson Lab, Lawrence Berkeley National Laboratory (LBNL), SLAC
National Accelerator Laboratory. We evaluate contemporary tools and
methodologies for information retrieval with Retrieval Augmented Generation
(RAGs), focusing on operational insights and integration with existing
accelerator control systems.
  The study addresses challenges and proposes solutions for state-of-the-art
eLog analysis through practical implementations, demonstrating applications and
limitations. We present a framework for enhancing accelerator facility
operations through improved information accessibility and knowledge management,
which could potentially lead to more efficient operations.

AI.tldr: This paper investigates how AI-driven tools, especially Retrieval Augmented Generation, enhance electronic logbook performance at accelerator facilities.
AI.motivation: There is a need to improve information retrieval and knowledge management systems in accelerator facilities for operational efficiency.
AI.method: Contemporary tools and methodologies for information retrieval were evaluated alongside practical implementations of RAG to assess eLog systems.
AI.result: The evaluation reveals operational insights, successful integration with current systems, and limitations of state-of-the-art eLog analysis.
AI.conclusion: The study proposes a framework for improving accelerator operations by optimizing information accessibility and eLog systems usage.

title: Hierarchical Group-wise Ranking Framework for Recommendation Models
summary:
In modern recommender systems, CTR/CVR models are increasingly trained with
ranking objectives to improve item ranking quality. While this shift aligns
training more closely with serving goals, most existing methods rely on
in-batch negative sampling, which predominantly surfaces easy negatives. This
limits the model's ability to capture fine-grained user preferences and weakens
overall ranking performance. To address this, we propose a Hierarchical
Group-wise Ranking Framework with two key components. First, we apply residual
vector quantization to user embeddings to generate hierarchical user codes that
partition users into hierarchical, trie-structured clusters. Second, we apply
listwise ranking losses to user-item pairs at each level of the hierarchy,
where shallow levels group loosely similar users and deeper levels group highly
similar users, reinforcing learning-to-rank signals through progressively
harder negatives. Since users with similar preferences and content exposure
tend to yield more informative negatives, applying ranking losses within these
hierarchical user groups serves as an effective approximation of hard negative
mining. Our approach improves ranking performance without requiring complex
real-time context collection or retrieval infrastructure. Extensive experiments
demonstrate that the proposed framework consistently enhances both model
calibration and ranking accuracy, offering a scalable and practical solution
for industrial recommender systems.

AI.tldr: The paper proposes a novel hierarchical ranking framework for recommender systems to enhance ranking performance through better negative sampling.
AI.motivation: Existing recommender systems often use in-batch negative sampling, which over-represents easy negatives, limiting the model's ability to capture nuanced user preferences and reducing ranking quality.
AI.method: The method introduces a Hierarchical Group-wise Ranking Framework, leveraging residual vector quantization for hierarchical user groupings and applying listwise ranking losses at various hierarchical levels to improve ranking signals.
AI.result: The proposed framework enhances both model calibration and ranking performance by approximating hard negative mining without requiring complex infrastructure.
AI.conclusion: The approach offers a scalable and efficient solution for improving ranking performance in industrial recommender systems while addressing limitations of existing negative sampling methods.

title: Nonlinear Model Order Reduction of Dynamical Systems in Process Engineering: Review and Comparison
summary:
Computationally cheap yet accurate enough dynamical models are vital for
real-time capable nonlinear optimization and model-based control. When given a
computationally expensive high-order prediction model, a reduction to a
lower-order simplified model can enable such real-time applications. Herein, we
review state-of-the-art nonlinear model order reduction methods and provide a
theoretical comparison of method properties. Additionally, we discuss both
general-purpose methods and tailored approaches for (chemical) process systems
and we identify similarities and differences between these methods. As
manifold-Galerkin approaches currently do not account for inputs in the
construction of the reduced state subspace, we extend these methods to
dynamical systems with inputs. In a comparative case study, we apply eight
established model order reduction methods to an air separation process model:
POD-Galerkin, nonlinear-POD-Galerkin, manifold-Galerkin, dynamic mode
decomposition, Koopman theory, manifold learning with latent predictor,
compartment modeling, and model aggregation. Herein, we do not investigate
hyperreduction (reduction of FLOPS). Based on our findings, we discuss
strengths and weaknesses of the model order reduction methods.

AI.tldr: The paper focuses on nonlinear model order reduction methods to simplify computationally expensive dynamical models for real-time applications. It presents a review, theoretical comparisons, and a case study on an air separation process.
AI.motivation: Real-time nonlinear optimization and control require simplified, computationally efficient dynamical models without compromising accuracy. The aim is to enable these models for effective real-time applications through model order reduction.
AI.method: The authors review existing nonlinear model reduction methods and perform a theoretical analysis of their properties. They extend manifold-Galerkin approaches to account for dynamical systems with inputs and apply eight different methods to a case study in chemical processes.
AI.result: A comparative analysis of eight model order reduction approaches was provided, with insights into their respective strengths and weaknesses, particularly in their application to an air separation process model.
AI.conclusion: By extending manifold-Galerkin methods and evaluating various reduction methods, this study highlights improvement areas while facilitating real-time capable modeling for complex dynamical systems.

title: NaSh: Guardrails for an LLM-Powered Natural Language Shell
summary:
We explore how a shell that uses an LLM to accept natural language input
might be designed differently from the shells of today. As LLMs may produce
unintended or unexplainable outputs, we argue that a natural language shell
should provide guardrails that empower users to recover from such errors. We
concretize some ideas for doing so by designing a new shell called NaSh,
identify remaining open problems in this space, and discuss research directions
to address them.

AI.tldr: The paper proposes NaSh, a natural language shell utilizing a large language model (LLM), and emphasizes the need for guardrails to handle unintended outputs.
AI.motivation: The motivation is to investigate the adaptation of shell systems to support natural language input using LLMs while addressing challenges posed by potential errors or unexplained outputs of LLMs.
AI.method: The authors design a prototype shell called NaSh that incorporates guardrails intended to help users recover from LLM errors. They also identify open research challenges in this domain.
AI.result: The study proposes NaSh, highlights potential solutions for integrating LLMs into shell environments, and identifies remaining open problems.
AI.conclusion: A new direction for shell design leveraging LLMs is presented, with strategies to manage errors and open questions encouraging further research.

title: SpaceTrack-TimeSeries: Time Series Dataset towards Satellite Orbit Analysis
summary:
With the rapid advancement of aerospace technology and the large-scale
deployment of low Earth orbit (LEO) satellite constellations, the challenges
facing astronomical observations and deep space exploration have become
increasingly pronounced. As a result, the demand for high-precision orbital
data on space objects-along with comprehensive analyses of satellite
positioning, constellation configurations, and deep space satellite
dynamics-has grown more urgent. However, there remains a notable lack of
publicly accessible, real-world datasets to support research in areas such as
space object maneuver behavior prediction and collision risk assessment. This
study seeks to address this gap by collecting and curating a representative
dataset of maneuvering behavior from Starlink satellites. The dataset
integrates Two-Line Element (TLE) catalog data with corresponding
high-precision ephemeris data, thereby enabling a more realistic and
multidimensional modeling of space object behavior. It provides valuable
insights into practical deployment of maneuver detection methods and the
evaluation of collision risks in increasingly congested orbital environments.

AI.tldr: This paper addresses the lack of publicly available datasets for space object behavior by curating a dataset from maneuvering Starlink satellite behaviors using TLE and high-precision ephemeris data.
AI.motivation: The rapid growth of aerospace technology and LEO satellite constellations has amplified challenges in astronomical observations, necessitating high-precision orbital data for tasks like collision risk assessment.
AI.method: The study compiled a dataset of Starlink satellite maneuver behaviors by integrating publicly available TLE data with high-precision ephemeris data.
AI.result: The resulting dataset enables realistic modeling of satellite behavior and supports maneuver detection and collision risk evaluation in congested orbital spaces.
AI.conclusion: By developing and making this dataset available, the study advances tools for understanding satellite maneuvers and managing risks in space operations.

title: Humans, Machine Learning, and Language Models in Union: A Cognitive Study on Table Unionability
summary:
Data discovery and table unionability in particular became key tasks in
modern Data Science. However, the human perspective for these tasks is still
under-explored. Thus, this research investigates the human behavior in
determining table unionability within data discovery. We have designed an
experimental survey and conducted a comprehensive analysis, in which we assess
human decision-making for table unionability. We use the observations from the
analysis to develop a machine learning framework to boost the (raw) performance
of humans. Furthermore, we perform a preliminary study on how LLM performance
is compared to humans indicating that it is typically better to consider a
combination of both. We believe that this work lays the foundations for
developing future Human-in-the-Loop systems for efficient data discovery.

AI.tldr: The study analyzes human behavior in determining table unionability in data discovery, designs an experimental survey, develops a machine learning framework to support humans, and suggests combining human input with large language models (LLMs).
AI.motivation: To address the under-explored human perspective in determining table unionability during data discovery tasks and enhance efficiency through a combined approach.
AI.method: Design of an experimental survey to assess human decision-making, comprehensive analysis of survey data, development of machine learning framework using survey observations, and preliminary comparison of LLM versus human performance.
AI.result: Experiments show human decision-making behaviors and demonstrate the efficacy of a machine learning framework to enhance human raw performance. Preliminary analysis suggests combining human efforts with LLM for better outcomes.
AI.conclusion: This research provides insights into human decision-making, introduces machine learning aiding frameworks, and proposes combining human input and LLMs for advancing Human-in-the-Loop systems in data discovery tasks.

title: Latent Representation Learning of Multi-scale Thermophysics: Application to Dynamics in Shocked Porous Energetic Material
summary:
Coupling of physics across length and time scales plays an important role in
the response of microstructured materials to external loads. In a multi-scale
framework, unresolved (subgrid) meso-scale dynamics is upscaled to the
homogenized (macro-scale) representation of the heterogeneous material through
closure models. Deep learning models trained using meso-scale simulation data
are now a popular route to assimilate such closure laws. However, meso-scale
simulations are computationally taxing, posing practical challenges in training
deep learning-based surrogate models from scratch. In this work, we investigate
an alternative meta-learning approach motivated by the idea of tokenization in
natural language processing. We show that one can learn a reduced
representation of the micro-scale physics to accelerate the meso-scale learning
process by tokenizing the meso-scale evolution of the physical fields involved
in an archetypal, albeit complex, reactive dynamics problem, \textit{viz.},
shock-induced energy localization in a porous energetic material. A
probabilistic latent representation of \textit{micro}-scale dynamics is learned
as building blocks for \textit{meso}-scale dynamics. The \textit{meso-}scale
latent dynamics model learns the correlation between neighboring building
blocks by training over a small dataset of meso-scale simulations. We compare
the performance of our model with a physics-aware recurrent convolutional
neural network (PARC) trained only on the full meso-scale dataset. We
demonstrate that our model can outperform PARC with scarce meso-scale data. The
proposed approach accelerates the development of closure models by leveraging
inexpensive micro-scale simulations and fast training over a small meso-scale
dataset, and can be applied to a range of multi-scale modeling problems.

AI.tldr: This paper explores a meta-learning approach using tokenization techniques to efficiently model meso-scale dynamics through information extracted from micro-scale simulations.
AI.motivation: The study aims to address challenges in computational costs associated with training deep learning surrogate models on meso-scale simulation data, which is crucial for understanding microstructured materials' responses.
AI.method: The authors employ a probabilistic latent representation of micro-scale dynamics to accelerate meso-scale learning. Tokenization techniques commonly used in NLP are adapted to correlate micro-scale and meso-scale building blocks.
AI.result: The proposed method outperforms a Physics-Aware Recurrent Convolutional Neural Network (PARC) regarding efficiency and accuracy, especially when using scarce meso-scale simulation data.
AI.conclusion: The research showcases an innovative and scalable approach to develop closure models for multi-scale systems by leveraging inexpensive micro-scale simulations and limited meso-scale datasets, applicable to diverse modeling challenges.

title: Personalizable Long-Context Symbolic Music Infilling with MIDI-RWKV
summary:
Existing work in automatic music generation has primarily focused on
end-to-end systems that produce complete compositions or continuations.
However, because musical composition is typically an iterative process, such
systems make it difficult to engage in the back-and-forth between human and
machine that is essential to computer-assisted creativity. In this study, we
address the task of personalizable, multi-track, long-context, and controllable
symbolic music infilling to enhance the process of computer-assisted
composition. We present MIDI-RWKV, a novel model based on the RWKV-7 linear
architecture, to enable efficient and coherent musical cocreation on edge
devices. We also demonstrate that MIDI-RWKV admits an effective method of
finetuning its initial state for personalization in the very-low-sample regime.
We evaluate MIDI-RWKV and its state tuning on several quantitative and
qualitative metrics, and release model weights and code at
https://github.com/christianazinn/MIDI-RWKV.
